proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Next Generation Enterprise Network (NGEN) is a Department of the Navy (DON) enterprise program (ACAT IAC) which provides secure, net-centric data and services to Navy and Marine Corps personnel. NGEN forms the foundation for the DON's future Naval Networking Environment (NNE), is interoperable with and leverages other DOD provided Net-Centric Enterprise Services and supports the Joint Information Environment (JIE). For the Marine Corps, NGEN is a Government Owned/Government Operated (GO/GO) model augmented by NGEN contractors with the garrison Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) representing the NGEN Marine Corps management domain. NGEN (USMC) supports the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) using a regionalized model, executed through Marine Forces Cyberspace Command, Marine Corps Cyberspace Operations Group (formerly Marine Corps Network Operations and Support Center (MCNOSC) and MAGTF IT Support Centers (MITSCs). The NGEN (USMC) program provides contractor support for the operation and support of the MCEN Non-secure Internet Protocol Router Network (MCEN-N) to include multiple contracts that provide equipment refresh. The program also supports hardware/software license and warranty generating lifecycle services ultimately enabling Cyber/Information Technology (CYBER/IT) capabilities for the Marine Corps in accordance with the NGEN Acquisition Strategy. This capabilities include enterprise infrastructure, end-user workstations, service desk, and network operations centers at Marine Corps base/post/stations and regional installation commands CONUS and OCONUS (Hawaii, Japan, Germany, and Korea).
NGEN will deliver an end-to-end hosting solution to consolidate and replace End-Of-Life (EOL) hardware/software (HW/SW) and infrastructure that currently provides enterprise network services (email, file storage, security services, identity management, etc.) to MCEN-N users (CONUS and OCONUS). It also provides High Availability/Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) capabilities that are not currently available in support of USMC Continuity of Operations (COOP) requirements. The requirement also includes the delivery of a Wide Area Network (WAN) transport solution based upon the JIE and Joint Regional Security Stack (JRSS) construct to consolidate and replace EOL HW/SW that currently provides enterprise network WAN transport services to MCEN-N users. As the consolidated, upgraded solution is developed, the program will continue to tech refresh end user devices, servers, routers, switches, network storage, software, initial equipment warranties, and defensive cyberspace capabilities (intrusion prevention systems, firewalls, etc.). The hardware and software for this refresh differs in quantities and costs based on varying requirements including the current pricing. The quantities that are ordered are based on hardware/software end of service/life limitations and the operational balance between security and risk management. Tech Refresh includes the design, configuration, functional testing, and integration of commercial or non-developmental network solutions to resolve and mitigate network security vulnerabilities in conjunction with newer technology insertion to improve reliability, improve maintainability, reduce cost, and/or add minor performance enhancement.
NACCR is an Abbreviated Acquisition Program (AAP) modification to the NGEN and SONIC Programs of Record (PORs) supporting the network access control concept on the MCEN. The NACCR end state solution provides an integrated capability allowing only authorized and compliant assets connection to the garrison enterprise network. This solution utilize 802.1X and Active Directory authentication protocols, as well as a series of compliance checks to ensure that critical software patches, anti-virus/anti-malware definitions and other established compliance criteria are current for assets on the network. It also generates trouble tickets as required and reports compliance standards. Any asset found to be non-compliant with the established criteria will be forced into a partially isolated network segment, where required remediation corrective actions will be taken. Should the automated remediation efforts prove unsuccessful after the prescribed number of attempts, the asset will be forced into a completely isolated network segment until it can be manually brought into compliance.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY18 Baseline Appropriation Request: $97.014M funding procured services, hardware and software supporting end user devices, network infrastructure technical refresh, and procurement of Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) equipment. Tech refresh supported the MCEN Unification Campaign Plan, Cyberspace Operations requirements, and the Marine Corps' implementation of the Joint Information Environment (JIE), which includes NIPR Installation Processing Nodes (IPN) critical design and site configuration. Tech Refresh included the design, configuration, and functional testing and integration of commercial or non-developmental network solutions to resolve and mitigate network security vulnerabilities. This was in conjunction with the insertion of newer technology to improve reliability, improve maintainability, reduce cost, and/or add minor performance enhancement. The DPRI Guam ($32K) NGEN requirement in FY18 supported MCEN-N access requirements for Marine Corps Activity Guam (MCAG) personnel needing computer assets.
Cost Elements in FY 2018 were updated to reflect actuals in PB20 because they were unable to be updated during the PB19. The FY 2018 End User Device quantities decreased from 23,500 to 9,750. The decrease was due to receiving an influx of funding from the FY 2017 ATR which provided for the procurement of additional End User Devices required to support the mandated WIN 10 transition. The remaining funds were realigned to address the reprioritization of efforts from Cost Elements 1.1.1 and 1.1.2 to Cost Element 1.1.3 for the upgrade/modernization of end of life/end of service equipment. If the equipment was not replaced, then it would have been removed from the network which would have caused network disruptions. This reprioritization aligns with the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control Strategy, transforming and optimizing the non-Classified Marine Corps Enterprise Network and directly supports DoD's Comply To Connect (C2C) initiative through network modernization. In addition, unit costs for End User Devices fluctuate from year to year due to changes in the quantities procured.
FY 2019 Baseline Appropriation Request: $82.120M ensures the Marine Corps is defending and protecting the MCEN against cyber-attacks and vulnerabilities. Funding procures services, hardware and software supporting end user devices, and network infrastructure technical refresh. Tech refresh supports the MCEN Unification Campaign Plan, Cyberspace Operations requirements, and the Marine Corps' implementation of the Joint Information Environment (JIE) which includes Enterprise Infrastructure Modernization (EIM) critical design and site configuration. Tech Refresh includes the design, configuration, and functional testing and integration of commercial or non-developmental network solutions to resolve and mitigate network security vulnerabilities. This is in conjunction with the insertion of newer technology to improve reliability, improve maintainability, reduce cost, and/or add minor performance enhancement. In addition, FY 2019 efforts include the continuation of WLAN implementation which will increase the operational readiness of operating forces and decrease maintenance time by allowing the maintainers to connect to technical manuals and maintenance systems while they are working. Currently maintainers must leave their work and go to a kiosk where there is a wired connection.
Cost Elements in FY 2019 were updated to reflect actuals. The $14.894M decrease in funding was primarily due to the reduction in EUDs purchased as a lingering effect from the greater number additional EUDs purchased to support that transition. The purchase reduction also required less field support funding. Changes when compared to PB 2019 were caused by the realignment of Marine Corps resources in order to implement and conform with the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control Strategy.
FY 2020 Baseline Appropriation Request: $114.901M will ensure the Marine Corps is defending and protecting the MCEN against cyber-attacks and vulnerabilities. Overall, FY 2020 funding increased $30.044M from FY 2019 which reflects the Marine Corps decision to align resources to Next Generation Enterprise Network Enhancement in order to replace aging and end-of-life network infrastructure which will increase the Marine Corps' Enterprise Network's reliability and security posture in order to defend the network against cyberattacks from both Nation-States and third party actors. The baseline appropriations request also includes $78K which is needed to procure End User Devices in support of MCB Guam personnel.
End User Device (Cost Element 1.1.1) funding increased from $5.001M in FY 2019 to $15.998M in FY 2020, a $10.997M increase, due to the refresh/replacement of End User Devices (EUDs) which will enable users to remain connected to the network with a fully compliant EUD. Replacing the aging EUDs will reduce the amount of equipment which is no longer receiving software patches or updates to operating systems which resolves cybersecurity vulnerabilities. If these EUDs are not replaced, then there will be an increased cyber security risk to the Marine Corps network which will lead to users being unable to connect to the network and perform their required duties as their non-compliant EUDs are removed from the network. Unit costs increase from FY 2019 to FY 2020 is due to inflation.
Fielding Support (Cost Element 1.1.2) funding increased from $0.763M in FY 2019 to $2.288M in FY 2020, a $1.525M increase due to increasing the quantity of EUDs purchased for refresh in FY 2020, 9,552 laptops. This cost element is directly related to changes in cost elements 1.1.1 and 1.1.3.
Network Equipment Tech Refresh (Cost Element 1.1.3) funding increased from $21.257M in FY 2019 to $60.262M in FY 2020, a $39.005M increase, due to reprioritizing efforts from Cost Elements 1.1.1 and 1.1.2 to Cost Element 1.1.3 for the upgrade/modernization of end of life/end of service equipment. This reprioritization aligns with the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control Strategy which focuses on transforming and optimizing the non-Classified side of the Marine Corps Enterprise Network and directly supports DoD's Comply To Connect (C2C) initiative through network modernization. Upgrades include the procurement of 802.1X access switches enabling the Network Access Control portion of the C2C requirement found in Section 1653 of the FY 2017 NDAA. Additionally, the equipment procured under this cost element will be replacing equipment that is no longer receiving security patches or updates from the vendor and is therefore more vulnerable to hostile actors and other cybersecurity vulnerabilities. If not replaced, these aging network devices will be removed from the network as a cybersecurity precaution and this will lead to Marine Corps users being unable to connect to the MCEN. The increase will enable the Marine Corps to replace the aging network devices with current cybersecurity standard compliant devices which will enable users across the Marine Corps to continue to operate without network disruptions.
Enterprise Infrastructure Modernization (EIM) (Cost Element 1.1.4) funding increased from $30.199M in FY 2019 to $30.353M in FY 2020, a $0.154M increase, due to inflation. Funding under this cost element provides for the upgrading and modernizing the Enterprise Service Stacks (ESS), Installation Processing Nodes (IPN), Installation Service Node (ISN) and Geographically Separated Units (GSU) across the non-Classified side of the Marine Corps Enterprise Network. These modernizations will support the Marine Corps' ability to migrate to the Joint Information Environment (JIE) and the cloud by increasing bandwidth which will enable individual and organizational mobility and supports the rapid deployment of mission critical applications and services. In addition, the migration to the cloud will result in reducing long network engineering/provision lead times.
Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) (Cost Element 1.1.5) funding decreased from $24.000M in FY 2019 to $6.000M in FY 2020, an $18.000M decrease, due to the ramping down of initial procurement of WLAN capabilities to the maintenance bays and stations. Funding in this cost element provides for the completion of the WLAN project at the initial maintenance bays and hangars installations. This effort will enable maintainers to access updated technical manual messages and updated maintenance information/alerts. The implementation of WLAN at maintenance bays and hangars, resulted in a 25% increase to the number of Ready Basic Aircraft due to efficiencies generated from WLAN.
Network Access Control Compliance and Remediation (Cost Element 1.2.1) funding decreased from $0.900M in FY 2019 to $0.000M in FY 2020, a $0.900M decrease due to the completion of initial fielding of the discovery tool identifying the physical devices on the network.

proc:Name.footnote: End User Device (Cost Element 1.1.1) funding increased from $5.001M in FY 2019 to $15.998M in FY 2020, a $10.997M increase. This is due to the return to a more normal refresh cycle following the plus up in FY18, that also affected FY19 EUD totals, to meet the DoD WIN10 compliance mandate. Unit costs increase from FY 2019 to FY 2020 is due to inflation.

proc:FiscalYear.footnote: Unit cost has been updated to actuals after contract award.

proc:ProcQuantity.footnote: FY 2018 quantities have been updated to actuals. The quantity decreased due to the FY 2017 ATR which provided funding to procurement of End User Devices in support of WIN 10 implementation.

proc:Name.footnote: The vendor for the FY 2019 tech refresh has not been determined, the vendor will be decided as part of the recompete effort.

proc:FiscalYear.footnote: Unit cost increases from FY 2019 to FY 2020 reflects inflation.

proc:Name.footnote: The Fielding Support (Cost Element 1.1.2) funding increased from $0.763M in FY 2019 to $2.288M in FY 2020, a $1.525M increase. This is due to additional assets, 9,552 laptops, procured in FY 2020 to replace aging EUDs. This cost element is directly related to changes in cost elements 1.1.1 and 1.1.3.

Network Equipment Tech Refresh (Cost Element 1.1.3) funding increased from $21.257M in FY 2019 to $60.262M in FY 2020. This reprioritization aligns with the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control Strategy which focuses on transforming and optimizing the non-Classified side of the Marine Corps Enterprise Network and directly supports DoD's Comply To Connect (C2C) initiative.
Enterprise Infrastructure Modernization (EIM) (Cost Element 1.1.4) This program had a $0.154M increase from FY19 to FY20 due to inflation.

Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) (Cost Element 1.1.5) funding decreased from $24.000M in FY 2019 to $6.000M in FY 2020. This is due to the near completion of the initial procurement of WLAN capabilities for maintenance bays and stations across the Marine Corps. The implementation of WLAN at maintenance bays and hangars, resulted in a 25% increase to the number of Ready Basic Aircraft due to efficiencies generated from WLAN.

Network Access Control Compliance and Remediation (Cost Element 1.2.1) funding decreased from $0.900M in FY 2019 to $0.000M in FY 2020, a $0.900M decrease due to the completion of initial fielding of the discovery tool identifying the physical devices on the network.

proc:CostElement.proc:Name: 1.2.1) Network Access Control, Compliance and Remediation (NACCR)

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Beginning in FY 2020, MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG), and UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS FORCES CYBERSPACE COMMAND (MARFORCYBER) were transferred to a new procurement line item, 4645 Cyberspace Activities, in order to consolidate Marine Corps Cyberspace Procurement Activities into one LI.
MARINE CORPS COMMON HARDWARE SUITE (MCHS) provides Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) laptops, workstations, software, servers, and other information technology (IT) hardware devices (ie Mobility) to support the Operating Forces and other Marine Corps customers. MCHS provides support for two principal groups: 1) United States Marine Corps (USMC) Tactical and Functional Programs of Record that use COTS IT hardware as part of their fielded systems, and 2) tactical and other Marine Corps customers not supported by Next Generation Enterprise Network (NGEN) such as Marine Corps Forces, Europe; Marine Corps Forces, Korea; Marine Corps Forces, Africa; and stand-alone Marine Corps units and schoolhouses.
FORMALIZED SCHOOLS TECHNICAL REFRESH (FSTR) funds and manages the software and IT hardware required to provide a robust and reliable Computer-Based Training (CBT) capability for TECOM (Training and Education Command) schools. Computers used in TECOM classrooms are not funded or managed by HQMC as part of the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN), and must therefore be funded and managed by the FSTR program. This program standardizes IT equipment for the 812 classrooms throughout TECOM and formalizes the upgrade and refresh process. In order to maintain adequate reliability and software compliance, computers need to be refreshed every four years. FSTR provides reliable hardware, software, and network resources to support Marine Corps Programs of Instruction and curriculum, delivered in TECOM formal classrooms. The FSTR program is foundational to realizing the Commandant of the Marine Corps' vision of exploiting technology as an enabler to advance Training & Education capabilities.
MARINE CORPS ENTERPRISE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY SERVICES (MCEITS) provides an overarching portfolio of capabilities to deliver "Power to the Edge" for the Marine Corps. Born from an effort to establish a Continuity of Operations Plan of Headquarters Marine Corps (HQMC) Automated Information Systems, MCEITS is a unifying framework of both the Net-Centric Enterprise Services to be delivered, and the infrastructure and systems which must be deployed to enable delivery of those services. MCEITS realigns the existing USMC environment of applications, databases, networks, and facilities into an integrated architecture. It provides the environment to access enterprise shared data and services while improving operational flexibility, responsiveness, and effectiveness for operating forces and the supporting establishment based on a common infrastructure and shared services. MCEITS allows for achievement of architectural standardization, consolidated management, seamless interoperability, and access to the data residing in our currently fielded applications (business and tactical). MCEITS enables access to enterprise information and provides the ability to collaborate and share information across the business and warfighter domains. MCEITS includes work to rationalize, modernize, virtualize, migrate, and host systems and applications residing in the Marine Corps enterprise information technology center (i.e., data center) located in Kansas City, Missouri. Additionally, MCEITS has a secondary, fail-over site located in Camp Lejuene, North Carolina, a System Integration Environment (SIE), and two Distributed Platforms. Procurement funding provides for various computers,network equipment, racks, etc., and associated installation costs.
MARINE CORPS RECRUITING INFORMATION SUPPORT SYSTEM (MCRISS) is an enterprise level system to automate administrative procedures for recruiting station operations. This customized automated System, centered on procedures in the Guidebook for Recruiters, Volume I, dramatically improves efficiency and effectiveness in Marine Corps recruiting. Furthermore, Military Entrance Processing Command requires Marine Corps recruiting to provide information in electronic format only. MCRISS is the Marine Corps Recruiting Command's program to manage applicant processing from commitment to accession/commission into the Marine Corps and Marine Corps Reserve. This enterprise approach allows for efficient sharing of information about potential recruits and recruiter screening efforts, yielding a more cost effective process.
MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG) (formerly MCNOSC) executes Marine Corps Global Information Grid Operations and Marine Corps Defensive Cyber Operations in support of Marine Corps operational requirements in order to enhance freedom of action across all warfighting domains, while denying the efforts of adversaries to degrade or disrupt this advantage through cyberspace. MCCOG is the Network Operations (NETOPS) component of Marine Corps Forces Cyberspace Command and provides network situational awareness, command and control, and technical support to Marine Corps operating forces and supporting establishment organizations, both in garrison and while deployed. MCCOG is the primary DOD Computer Network Defense Service Provider for the U.S. Marine Corps and directs Service actions to prevent and respond to security incidents. The MCCOG delivers numerous enterprise services for the Marine Corps, to include mainframe computer services management, Defense Message System (DMS), DOD Public Key Infrastructure (PKI), and Active Directory/Global Address List. The MCCOG is responsible for the operations and defense of MCEITS, which delivers data center services to the Marine Corps. Finally, MCCOG provides technical expertise to HQMC, Marine Corps Combat Development Command (MCCDC), Marine Corps Systems Command (MCSC), and Marine Corps organizations around the world in support of Information Technology initiatives undertaken within the Marine Corps and DOD. The PMC funding will support Core Competencies in the Computer Networks Defense and NETOPS areas with skilled cyber-warriors (24x7x365). The added responsibilities and network security events have required continued operational employment of current assets and personnel. PMC funding is based on increased mission requirements dictated by DoD/USSTRATCOM/USCYBERCOM to defend the network. The procurement funding will be used to refresh the MCCOG Alternate Network Operations Security Center, USMC Site R refresh, Network Common Operational Picture Tools, Host Based Security Systems, Secure Configuration Compliance Validation Initiative and Secure Configuration Remediation Initiative (SCCVI/SCRI), Intrusion Prevention and scanning tools, Virtual Private Network, and other operations and defense tools. Beginning in FY20 this effort moves to LI 4645.
SECURE OPERATIONAL NETWORK INFRASTRUCTURE AND COMMUNICATIONS (SONIC) program provides funding to procure and support hardware, software, infrastructure and services necessary to support and improve critical C2 network operations. This funding enables central management of refresh and sustainment of hardware, software, and the infrastructure necessary to provide network services on the USMC Garrison SIPRNET. This ensures enterprise architecture goals and standards are established and maintained and takes advantage of quantity-related discounts. The SIPRNET provides Marine Corps garrison forces with a secure digital means to communicate and share data, information, and knowledge at the secret level with dispersed organizations located around the world. SONIC resources the tech refresh of technologically obsolete equipment, shortfalls in network operational capabilities, solutions to resolve and mitigate network security vulnerabilities, and technology insertion for increased SIPRNET capability as expressed by the Marine Corps Forces (MARFORs). Tech Refresh includes the design, configuration, and functional testing and integration of commercial or non-developmental network solutions to resolve and mitigate network security vulnerabilities.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATION PROGRAM (MCIOP) supports DOD capabilities based analysis (CBA) to address emerging Marine Air Ground Task Force C2 program and cyberspace requirements. MCIOP supports Information Operations (IO) Range research/modeling/simulation conducted by Marine Corps Warfighting Lab (MCWL), industry, and/or academia to explore existing and emergent Information Operations initiatives and cyber technologies.
UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS FORCES CYBERSPACE COMMAND (MARFORCYBER) will procure hardware and software for Deployable Mission Support Systems (DMSS). DMSS kits are maintained with hardware support and software renewals, and refresh perpetual software licenses for DMSS kits. Beginning in FY20 this effort moves to LI 4645.
PAPERLESS ACQUISITION (PA) SYSTEMS is comprised of two programs, Purchase Request Builder (PR Builder) and Standard Procurement System / Procurement Desktop Defense (SPS/PD2). PR Builder is a fully web-based, Mission Assurance Category (MAC) III sensitive business system. SPS/PD2, part of the Joint SPS Acquisition Program, is the USMC's authoritative contracting generation system within the Marine Corps' electronic Systems Business Enterprise. Both of these systems provide system-to-system interface with other DoD financial management systems which include Standard Accounting, Budgeting, and Reporting System (SABRS), Federal Government's Electronic Document Access system (EDA), and Invoice, Receipt Acceptance and Property Transfer.
TECHNOLOGY SERVICES ORGANIZATION (TSO):provides development, testing, and production hosting environments in support of the Marine Corps enterprise pay, personnel, accounting and financial management systems to include Marine Corps Total Force System (MCTFS), Marine Online, Marine Corps Orders Resource System (MCORS), Standards Accounting, Budgeting and Reporting System (SABRS), and the Marine Corps Financial Integrated Analysis System (MCFIAS). The TSO also provides complete SDLC activities for these systems as well as development of the Navy, Air Guard, and Air Force Reserve Order Writing Systems. The TSO is implementing the Marine Corp's SABRS application to the Department of the Navy.
PROFESSIONALL DEVELOPMENT - MARINE CORPS UNIVERSITY: The Professional Development Program develops, delivers, and evaluates Professional Military Education (PME) and training through resident and distance education programs to prepare leaders to meet the challenges of the national security environment. The .edu expansion provides wireless connectivity, information sharing, and audio visual capabilities in support of Education Command's effort to modernize PME. Having .edu networks at all of the Marine Corp University campuses creates the opportunity for courses to collaborate, conduct research, wargame, and conduct video teleconferencing.
[P40A / Data Center Tech Refresh]: Datacenter Tech Refresh (Cost Element 1.3.7) funding decreased from $19.118M in FY 2019 to $18.010M in FY 2020, a $1.108M decrease. This is due to a strategic change to incrementally implement tech refresh annually instead of a 5-year "rip and replace" strategy. Infrastructure procured under this cost element will replace equipment essential to sustaining capabilities in the datacenter. The replacement of aging and non-compliant infrastructure is required to support emerging cybersecurity standards and compliance directives. If infrastructure is not replaced, this will put the existing system at risk for Cybersecurity vulnerabilities which result in the inability to share critical mission essential data across the Marine Corps.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
Beginning in FY 2020, MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG), and UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS FORCES CYBERSPACE COMMAND (MARFORCYBER) were transferred to a new procurement line item, 4645 Cyberspace Activities, in order to consolidate Marine Corps Cyberspace Procurement Activities into one LI.
FY 2018 Justifications:
MARINE CORPS COMMON HARDWARE SUITE (MCHS) Programs of Record listed in the description have been moved to their respective BLIs starting in FY18 for execution and will not be included under the MCHS POR in this exhibit (See Program Description for full list of programs).
Marine Corps Common Hardware (MCHS) FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $2.354M supported the purchase of hardware/software for Marine Forces Europe/Marine Forces Korea (MARFORE/MARFORK) and the Enterprise Staging & Warehousing effort (ES&W) that includes the receipt, inventory, imaging, kitting, and shipping (RIIKS) of IT hardware to MFE/MFA, MFK, and OPFORs (shipped in a standard configuration ready to use).
FORMALIZED SCHOOLS TECHNICAL REFRESH (FSTR) FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $3.275M supported TECOM classroom refresh and tablet procurement.
SECURE OPERATIONAL NETWORK INFRASTRUCTURE AND COMMUNICATIONS (SONIC) FY18 Baseline Appropriation Request: $20.869M funding procured services, hardware and software supporting end user devices, network infrastructure technical refresh, and procurement of Encryptors equipment. Tech refresh supported the MCEN Unification Campaign Plan, Cyberspace Operations requirements, and the Marine Corps' implementation of the Joint Information Environment (JIE). Tech Refresh includes design, configuration, and functional testing and integration of commercial or non-developmental network solutions to resolve and mitigate network security vulnerabilities on the SIPRNet. This is in conjunction with the insertion of newer technology to improve reliability, improve maintainability, reduce cost, and/or add minor performance enhancement.
Changes as compared to PB 2019 were caused by the realignment of Marine Corps resources in order to align with the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control Strategy. FY 2018 SIPR End User Device quantities decreased from 11,226 to 2,112 due to receiving FY 2017 funding. These devices were critical to service WIN 10 implementation. In addition, unit costs for End User Devices fluctuate from year to year due to changes in the quantities procured. Cost Elements in FY 2018 were updated to reflect actuals.
MARINE CORPS ENTERPRISE IT SERVICES (MCEITS) FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $3.207M supported scaling of 1st and 2nd MCEITS IT Center infrastructures to host additional applications planned for migration and to procure hardware for an Application and Development/test environment. Changes compared to PB 2019 were caused by the realignment of Marine Corps resources in order to align with the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control Strategy, funding was realigned to the MARFORK EIM Cost Element (Cost Element 1.1).
MARINE CORPS RECRUITING INFORMATION SUPPORT SYSTEM (MCRISS) FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $0.049M provided mission critical software required to support the needs of Marine Corps Recruiting Information Support System.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATION PROGRAM (MCIOP) FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $0.398M provided mission critical hardware such as workstations and software that are specific to the needs of the intelligence environment. Modeling and simulation explores existing and emergent Information Operations (IO) initiatives and cyber technologies.
PAPERLESS ACQUISITION (PA) SYSTEMS FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $0.122M provided mission critical hardware required to support the needs of Paperless Acquisition Systems such as Standard Procurement System (SPS), Electronic Procurement System (EPS), and Purchase Request Builder (PRB).
TECHNOLOGY SERVICES ORGANIZATION (TSO) FY 2018 Base Appropriation request: $1.305M supported laptop and server refresh to include hardware and software supporting the development of Marine Corps enterprise HRM and Financial Management systems. This Technical refresh/upgrade of SABRS database technology from ADABAS to a newer database architecture provides a modern and well-supported database technology that ultimately enables the normalization of Marine Corps financial data in a true relational database.
MARFORCYBER: FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $20.924M of which $10.022M completed MARFORCYBER's headquarters MILCON facility on the East Campus at Fort Meade. It also completed the FY14 MILCON project number P001 items such as Distributed Computing Equipment, Video Teleconferencing and Multi-media Equipment, Network Hardware, Telephone Equipment, Cable Infrastructure, Wireless Center, and Operations Center. Remaining funding procured hardware and software for Deployable Mission Support Systems (DMSS). DMSS kits are maintained with hardware support, software renewals, and refresh perpetual software licenses. DMSS kits are required in order for MARFORCYBER to support Marine units all across the globe.
FY 2019 Justifications:
Marine Corps Common Hardware (MCHS) FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $0.934M supports the purchase of hardware/software for Marine Forces Europe/Marine Forces Korea (MARFORE/MARFORK) and the Enterprise Staging & Warehousing effort (ES&W) that includes the receipt, inventory, imaging, kitting and shipping (RIIKS) of IT hardware to MFE/MFA, MFK, and OPFORs (shipped in a standard configuration ready to use).
FORMALIZED SCHOOLS TECHNICAL REFRESH (FSTR) FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $6.764M funding supports procurement of tablets for TECOM classrooms throughout the Marine Corps. Additionally, classrooms for USMC Military Occupational Specialty (MOS) formal schools will be updated and refreshed.
SECURE OPERATIONAL NETWORK INFRASTRUCTURE AND COMMUNICATIONS (SONIC) FY 2019 Baseline Appropriation Request: $13.285M ensures the Marine Corps continues to defend and protect the MCEN-S against cyber-attacks and vulnerabilities. Funding procures services, hardware and software supporting Classified End User Devices, and network infrastructure technical refresh. Tech refresh, in conjunction with the insertion of newer technology to improve reliability, improve maintainability, reduce cost, and/or add minor performance enhancement, supports the MCEN Unification Campaign Plan, Cyberspace Operations requirements, and the Marine Corps' implementation of the Joint Information Environment (JIE) which includes Enterprise Infrastructure Modernization (EIM) critical design and site configuration. Tech Refresh also includes the design, configuration, and functional testing and integration of commercial or non-developmental network solutions to resolve and mitigate network security vulnerabilities within the classified network. In addition, FY 2019 efforts include the continuation of the Virtual Desktop Infrastructure being fielded at four sites.
Cost Elements in FY 2019 were updated to reflect actuals. Changes compared to PB 2019 were caused by the realignment of Marine Corps resources in order to align with the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control Strategy. FY 2019 Classified End User Device quantities increased from 2,112 to 2,683 due to the decrease in unit cost allowing for more devices to be procured.
MARINE CORPS ENTERPRISE IT SERVICES (MCEITS) FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $19.118M supports technical refresh and domain consolidation for all MCEITS IT Center infrastructures hosting environments. Funding supports additional application migrations and hardware/software procurements for the Application and Development/test environment and sustainment engineering changes.
MARINE CORPS RECRUITING INFORMATION SUPPORT SYSTEM (MCRISS) FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $0.362M; Funding supports mission critical software licenses required to support the Modernization of Marine Corps Recruiting Information Support System.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATION PROGRAM (MCIOP) FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $0.408M provides mission critical hardware and software that are specific to the needs of the intelligence environment. Modeling and simulation explores existing and emergent Information Operations (IO) initiatives and cyber technologies.
PAPERLESS ACQUISITION (PA) SYSTEMS FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $0.124M provides mission critical hardware required to support the needs of Paperless Acquisition Systems such as Standard Procurement System (SPS), Electronic Procurement System (EPS), and Purchase Request Builder (PRB).
TECHNOLOGY SERVICES ORGANIZATION (TSO) FY 2019 Base Appropriation request: $0.878M supports laptop and server refresh to include hardware and software supporting the development of Marine Corps enterprise HRM and Financial Management systems.
MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG): FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $7.683M procures hardware and software for Defensive Cyber Operations support and network infrastructure upgrades.
MARFORCYBER: FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $13.348M procures hardware and software for Deployable Mission Support Systems (DMSS). DMSS kits are maintained with hardware support, software renewals, and refresh perpetual software licenses. DMSS kits are required in order for MARFORCYBER to support Marine Corps units all across the globe. $8.488M procures DMSS kits for MARFORCYBER and $4.860M procures DMSS kits for the Marine Corps Operating Forces.
FY 2020 Justifications:
Marine Corps Common Hardware (MCHS) FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $0.953M will support the purchase of hardware/software for Marine Forces Europe/Marine Forces Korea (MARFORE/MARFORK) and the Enterprise Staging & Warehousing effort (ES&W) that includes the receipt, inventory, imaging, kitting, and shipping (RIIKS) of IT hardware to MFE/MFA, MFK, and OPFORs (shipped in a standard configuration ready to use).
End User Device (Cost Element 1.2) funding increased from $0.712M in FY 2019 to $0.731M in FY 2020, a $0.019M increase, due to the replacement End User Devices (EUDs) that are becoming non-compliant for users at MARFORK and MARFOREUR, this replacement will enable users to remain connected to the network with a fully compliant EUD. Unit costs increase from FY 2019 to FY 2020 due to inflation.
Fielding Support (Cost Element 1.6) $0.222M will support the fielding of equipment that is procured through other customer funds. The type of support provided includes the creation of the birth record for equipment to ensure that the equipment can be accounted for in property accountability systems, along with configuring and kitting the equipment to ensure it is consistent with Marine Corps IT standards.
FORMALIZED SCHOOLS TECHNICAL REFRESH (FSTR) FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $6.905M funding will support Training and Education Command (TECOM) schoolhouse classroom computer refresh and tablet procurements. The Marine Corps operates 62 Military Occupational Specialty (MOS) producing schools, with an established AAO of over 10,000 computers, required to deliver training and education curriculum. Costs are driven by IT equipment refresh, enterprise software licensing, computer imaging/shipping, and industry best practices.
SECURE OPERATIONAL NETWORK INFRASTRUCTURE AND COMMUNICATIONS (SONIC) FY 2020 Baseline Appropriation Request: $13.946M will ensure the Marine Corps continues to defend and protect the MCEN-S against cyber-attacks and vulnerabilities. The overall FY20 funding increase of $0.652M from FY 2019 reflects the Marine Corps decision to align resources to Secure Operational Network Infrastructure and Communications enhancement in order to replace aging and end-of-life network infrastructure. This increases the Marine Corps Enterprise Network's reliability and security posture against cyberattacks from both Nation-States and third party actors. The baseline appropriations request also includes $9K which is needed to procure Classified End User Devices in support of MCB Guam personnel.
End User Device (Cost Element 5.1) funding increased from $3.000M in FY 2019 to $4.000M in FY 2020, a $1.000M increase, due to the replacement of Classified End User Devices (EUDs) enabling users to remain connected to the network with a fully compliant EUD. Replacing the aging EUDs will reduce the cybersecurity vulnerabilities arising from these items no longer receiving support or updates. If these EUDs are not replaced, it will be necessary for these users to be removed from the network to protect against cyber threats, thereby resulting in an inability to perform mission essential duties.
The Field Support (Cost Element 5.2) funding increased from $0.254M in FY 2019 to $0.268M in FY 2020, a $0.014M increase, due to increasing the quantity of 2,683 laptops procured in FY 2020 to replace aging Classified EUDs, which were procured at the beginning stages of the WIN 10 implementation. This cost element is directly related to changes in cost elements 5.1 and 5.3.
Network Equipment Tech Refresh (Cost Element 5.3) funding decreased from $6.847M in FY 2019 to $5.598M in FY 2020, a $1.249M decrease, due to reprioritizing efforts from Cost Elements 5.3 to Cost Element 5.4 for the modernization of service equipment upgrading and modernizing the Classified Enterprise Service Stacks (ESS-S). This reprioritization aligns with the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control Strategy which focuses on transforming and optimizing the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN). In addition, the equipment procured under this cost element will be replacing outdated equipment that is no longer receiving security patches or updates from the vendor, increasing cybersecurity vulnerabilities across the MCEN-S. If not replaced, these aging network devices will be removed from the network as a result of not receiving cybersecurity updates which will lead to Marine Corps users being unable to connect to the MCEN. Funding within this cost element will enable the Marine Corps to replace these aging network devices with ones that are compliant with current cybersecurity standards which will enable users across the Marine Corps to continue to operate without network disruptions.
Enterprise Infrastructure Modernization Classified (EIM-S) (Cost Element 5.4) funding increased from $3.000M in FY 2019 to $4.080M in FY 2020, a $1.080M increase, for the modernization of the Classified Enterprise Infrastructure. Funding under this cost element provides for upgrading and modernizing the Classified Enterprise Service Stacks (ESS-S), Classified Installation Processing Nodes CLASSIFIED (IPN-S), Classified Installation Service Node (ISN-S) and Geographically Separated Units (GSU) across the Marine Corps within the classified environment. These modernizations will support the Marine Corps' ability to migrate to the Joint Information Environment (JIE) and the cloud by increasing bandwidth, enhancing individual and organizational mobility, and supporting the rapid deployment of mission critical applications and services. In addition, the migration to the cloud will result in reduced long network engineering/provision lead times.
Network Access Control Compliance and Remediation (Cost Element 5.5) funding decreased from $.184M in FY 2019 to $0M in FY 2020, a $.184M decrease due to the completion of initial fielding of the discovery tool identifying the physical devices on the network.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATION PROGRAM (MCIOP) FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $0.416M supports additional hardware refreshes and also will provide mission critical hardware and software that is specific to the needs of the intelligence environment. Modeling and simulation explores existing and emergent Information Operations (IO) initiatives and cyber technologies. The $0.008M increase in funding from FY19 to FY20 is due to the hardware refresh schedule.
MARINE CORPS RECRUITING INFORMATION SUPPORT SYSTEM (MCRISS) FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $0.050M will support software licenses which are mission critical and required to support the Modernization of Marine Corps Recruiting Information Support System.
PAPERLESS ACQUISITION (PA) SYSTEMS FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $0.127M will provide mission critical hardware required to support the needs of Paperless Acquisition Systems such as Standard Procurement System (SPS), Electronic Procurement System (EPS), and Purchase Request Builder (PRB).
MARINE CORPS ENTERPRISE IT SERVICES (MCEITS) FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $18.010M supports technical refresh for all MCEITS IT Center infrastructures hosting environments. Funding supports additional application migrations, hardware/software procurements for the Application and Development/test environment, and sustainment engineering changes.
Datacenter Tech Refresh (Cost Element 1.3.7) funding decreased from $19.118M in FY 2019 to $18.010M in FY 2020, a $1.108M decrease. This is due to a strategic change to incrementally implement tech refresh annually instead of a 5-year "rip and replace" strategy. Infrastructure procured under this cost element will replace equipment essential to sustaining capabilities in the datacenter. The replacement of aging and non-compliant infrastructure is required to support emerging cybersecurity standards and compliance directives. If infrastructure is not replaced, this will put the existing system at risk for Cybersecurity vulnerabilities which result in the inability to share critical mission essential data across the Marine Corps.
Data Center Domain Consolidation (Cost Element 1.3.8) funding decreased from $10.060M in FY 2019 to $0.000M in FY 2020. This effort completed in FY 2019.
PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT - MARINE CORPS UNIVERSITY FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $6.796M. $1.478M will support the .edu network capacity upgrade will allow five Staff Non-Commissioned Officer Academies (SNCOA) at locations CONUS and OCONUS to be brought on the .edu network. The current network which supports only Marine Corps University at Marine Corps Base Quantico and the SNCOA at Camp Johnson is at capacity which does not allow for any additional capabilities. $5.318M will support the SNCOA, Camp Pendleton .edu expansion will provide wireless connectivity, information sharing and audio visual capabilities in support of EDCOM's effort to modernize Professional Military Education (PME). This is the next step in expanding the capability which ensures that students receive the same access to information and education that students attending the Quantico and CP Johnson campuses receive. SNCOA campuses that rely on the .mil network for access to resources are restricted and often blocked from sites not approved by .mil hardening efforts. Having .edu networks at all of the MCU campuses creates the opportunity for courses to collaborate, conduct research, wargame, and conduct video teleconferencing.
TECHNOLOGY SERVICES ORGANIZATION (TSO) FY 2020 Base Appropriation request: $3.891M supports laptop and network device procurement that enables the development of Marine Corps enterprise HRM and Financial Management systems. This includes the maintenance of the Marine Corps Total Force System (MCTFS), Marine Online (MOL), Marine Corps Orders Resource System (MCORS), Standard Accounting, Budgeting & Reporting System (SABRS) and the Marine Corps Financial Integrated Analysis System (MCFIAS). This Technical refresh/upgrade of SABRS database technology from ADABAS to a newer database architecture provides a modern and well-supported database technology that ultimately enables the normalization of Marine Corps financial data in a true relational database. The increase of $3M from FY19 to FY20 is funding for MOL Modernization as part of the HR2025 initiative.

proc:Category.proc:Name: 9) Marine Corps Recruiting Information Support System (MCRISS)

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Networking On The Move (NOTM) - Provides a command and control (C2) capability by integrating tactical data systems with on the move satellite communications (SATCOM) for beyond line-of-sight ability that allows battlefield commanders to have uninterrupted two-way access to digital data, anywhere on the battlefield. NOTM provides Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) commanders and staffs with full Common Operational Picture (COP) access, virtually unlimited situational awareness and a powerful ability to issue digital orders (fires, maneuver, planning) to Ground Combat Element (GCE), Air Combat Element (ACE) and Logistics Combat Element (LCE) units at all echelons while on-the-move or at-the-halt. NOTM also provides Marine units the capability to link with and extend Defense Information System Network (DISN) services; SIPRNet, NIPRNet, and Defense Switched Networks (DSN). Integrated full motion video (receipt and retransmission), tactical voice communications, plus three options for secure wireless local area network (LAN) connectivity between staff members makes this capability a crucial asset to all elements of the MAGTF. Currently the USMC has three variants depending on the type of transportation being used; the NOTM Ground Combat Vehicle (GCV), NOTM Utility Task Vehicle (UTV), and NOTM Airborne (NOTM-A).
Joint Battle Command - Platform (JBC-P) Family of Systems (FoS) - JBC-P FoS is an Army led ACAT II program of Joint Requirements Oversight Council (JROC) interest formerly known as the Blue Force Tracker (BFT) FoS. It is comprised of L-Band Satellite Communications (SATCOM) and is a digital, battle command information FoS that provides integrated, on the move, timely, relevant Command and Control Situational Awareness (C2SA) information to tactical combat, combat support, and combat service support commanders, leaders, and key C2 nodes. JBC-P FoS will provide JROC mandated C2SA convergence across Combat Operations Centers (COC), ground vehicles and dismounted personnel.
Global Command and Control System - Tactical Combat Operations System (GCCS-TCO) - GCCS-TCO is the principal tool within the MAGTF for situational awareness through distribution of the Common Tactical Picture (CTP). It supports tactical operations by providing information via high speed computer systems in a timely manner and includes the Tactical COP Workstations/Servers. Procurement funding allows for system refresh and replacements to match the program's acquisition objective.
Advanced Field Artillery Tactical Data Family of Systems (AFATDS FoS) - AFATDS FoS consists of three programs: AFATDS, Back Up Computer System (BUCS), and Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS). The AFATDS automates the fires planning, tactical fire direction, and fire support coordination required to support maneuver from the sea and subsequent operations ashore. AFATDS integrates all supporting arms assets within the MAGTF such as mortars, cannon artillery, rockets and missiles, close air support, and naval surface fire support systems. BUCS is a hand-held computer system designed to provide a backup to the AFATDS in computing ballistic firing solutions as well as provide survey and meteorological functions in support of artillery. Additionally, BUCS is the primary ballistic firing solution system during Ship To Objective Maneuver (STOM) and for the Expeditionary Fire Support System (EFSS). The MTS is a Lightweight Multi-purpose Shelter (LMS) mounted on a High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV) which protects both the AFATDS and operators from the environment. MTS enables rapid emplacement and displacement of fire support elements and provides networked communications on the move. Transition to BLI 4733 in FY19.
Target Hand-Off System (THS) - The THS addresses a Marine Corps operational requirement for a lightweight, handheld, and digital target acquisition engagement coordination system. The THS is interoperable with all Fire Support platforms and Target Locating Devices designed for the Forward Air Controllers (FACs), Forward Observers (FOs), Fire Support Teams (FSTs), Firepower Control Teams (FCTs), Tactical Air Control Parties (TACPs), and Reconnaissance Teams. The THS provides the ability to quickly acquire and digitally prosecute targets in day, night, and near-all-weather visibility conditions in order to conduct precise and rapid indirect surface fire support, Naval Surface Fire Support (NSFS), and Close Air Support (CAS). Transition to BLI 4733 in FY19.
Marine Corps Information Operation Program (MCIOP) - provides MAGTF commanders and the Marine Corps a responsive and effective full-spectrum information operations (IO) planning and psychological operations delivery capability by means of deployable support teams and a comprehensive general support IO reach-back capability in order to integrate IO into Marine Corps operations. Multiple classification levels require separate Information Technology (IT) infrastructure to support each classification level in accordance with National Security Agency and Defense Intelligence Agency standards. This includes equipment necessary for connecting internal MCIOC IT infrastructure (voice, video, and data) with the existing Marine Corps Base Quantico support infrastructure. Transition to BLI 4620 in FY19.
Combat Operations Center (COC) - The COC provides commanders with a rapidly deployable, common, modular, and scalable operational agency that facilitates command and control across the full spectrum of MAGTF operations. The AN/TSQ-239A Family of Systems (FoS) is designed to provide centralized C2 Operational Facilities (OPFAC) to collect, process, and disseminate tactical data for the commander and staff of a Marine Expeditionary Force (MEF), Division, Wing, Marine Logistics Group, Regiment, Marine Air Group, Battalion, and Squadron. The COC provides the commander with a Common Operational Picture (COP) and tactical data and communications assets needed to plan and conduct operations in an expeditionary combat environment. The system enables analytical and intuitive decision-making with a modular and scalable equipment set consisting of a common module OPFAC, C2 system, visual displays, and SW. Existing Tactical Data System software, previously resident on numerous platforms throughout the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF), have been re-hosted on the COC system to provide commanders with integrated data access and communications.
Hand Held Command and Control (H2C2) - Provides the dismounted user at the tactical edge, a handheld devices that provides integrated, on-the-move, secure, timely, and relevant Command & Control/Situational Awareness (C2/SA) information to tactical combat, combat support and combat service support commanders, leaders, and key C2 nodes. H2C2 provides leaders with a capability for selecting, managing, and assimilating relevant data and information. This allows them to pass orders and graphics that will provide the joint warfighter the capability to visualize the commander's intent and scheme of maneuver, and provide enhanced SA of friendly, reported enemy, neutral, and civilian entities.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY2018 Base Appropriation Request: $203.860M ($202.411M Active; $1.449M Reserves)
Networking On The Move (NOTM): $117.014M ($117.013M Active; $0.001M Reserves) - FY18 funding supported production, procurement and fielding of the NOTM-GCV and NOTM-A. Funds also supported procurement of components and equipment for refresh and upgrades and acquisition training, and fielding efforts associated with production systems.
Global Command and Control System - Tactical Combat Operations (GCCS-TCO): $0.689M ($0.300M Active; $0.389M Reserves) - FY18 funding in the amount of $2.575M was realigned to the JBC-P program to procure the Handheld End User Device (HHEUD) Early Capability Release (ECR). Funding was realigned due to the delay of technology readiness of workstations (laptops). The remaining $0.300 in the active line and $0.389M in the reserve line will procure technical refresh of "workstations" (laptops/clients) across the operational forces.
Joint Battle Command - Platform Family of Systems (JBC-P FoS): $41.678M Active - Increased JBCP funding of $6.075 from PB19 to PB20 due to Marine Corps prioritized below threshold realignment of funds to procure the Handheld End User Device (HHEUD) Early Capability Release (ECR). FY18 funding continued to provide support for items such as, software and hardware integration, hardware refresh, ancillary equipment, New Equipment Training (NET) and field support, and procures mounted family of computer systems (MFoCS).
Advanced Field Artillery Tactical Data Systems (AFATDS): $10.199M Active - FY18 funds procured a modernized, common shelter that fulfills the requirements of the Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS) and the Target Processing Set (TPS). Funds support critical hardware refresh for a laptop procurement which is essential to ensure AFATDS is windows 10 compliant.
Target Hand-off System (THS): $17.985M Active - FY18 was used to replace AN/PRC-117F radios with AN/PRC-117G radios. This upgrade enabled THS to operate on the ANW2 network providing THS digital interoperability with AFATDS and multiple air platforms. This enabled Fires Controllers to perform target acquisition, location, and digital hand-off of targets to air and ground weapon platforms. Realignment of effort to new Budget Line Item (4733) in FY 19 and beyond reflects USMC Program Management Office (PMO) reorganization to improve support of USMC OPFOR.
Marine Corps Information Operation Program (MCIOP): $0.110M Active - FY18 funding provided tactical server refresh.
Combat Operations Center (COC): $16.185M ($15.126M Active; 1.059M Reserves) - FY18 funds supported the fielding of the (V)1-4 hardware refresh in support of a common hardware baseline. Funding also used to align the COC software baseline with systems currently hosted within the COC (AFATDS, CDN) in order to manage software growth and interoperability. Supporting the existing software baseline is necessary to maintain Authority To Operate (ATO) and integration with Tactical Service Oriented Architecture (TSOA), Joint Tactical Command Operations Picture (COP) Workstation (JTCW) and Command and Control Personal Computer (C2PC).
FY2019 Base Appropriation Request: $115.873M ($113.715 Active, $2.158 Reserves)
Networking On The Move (NOTM): $92.669M ($92.662M Active; $0.007M Reserves) - Decrease of $24.345M from FY18 to FY19 is due to the acceleration of the NOTM-A procurement schedule. FY19 funds procure NOTM-GCV, NOTM-A systems and NOTM-GCV retrofit kits to reduce size, weight and power (SWaP). Funds will also provide component and equipment upgrades, production, fielding and training support.
Global Command and Control System - Tactical Combat Operations (GCCS-TCO): $0.380M Active -Decrease of $0.309M funding from FY18 to FY19 aligns to procurement schedule and decrease of reserve funding due to planned completion of tech refresh. FY19 funding procures a 3yr JavaBeans Open Source Software (JBOSS) software subscription for the Tactical Common Operational Picture (COP) Servers (TCS) which is required for the TCS 6.X software baseline and deployed across the operational forces.
Joint Battle Command - Platform Family of Systems (JBC-P FoS): $17.056M Active - Decrease of $24.622M from FY18 to FY19 is aligned to the schedule for HHEUD, MFoCS, hardware refresh, and associated fielding support. FY19 funds continues support for items such as, software and hardware integration, hardware refresh, ancillary equipment, NET and field support, and procures Mounted Family of Computer Systems (MFoCS).
Combat Operations Center (COC): $5.768M ($3.617M Active; $2.151M Reserves) - FY19 funds required for hardware refresh supporting existing software baseline.
FY2020 Base Appropriation Request: $108.897 ($106.699M Active, $2.198M Reserve)
The FY2020 Base funding request decreases from FY 2019 by $6.976 million primarily due to the completion of 69% of the AAO for three variants (Ground Combat Vehicle, NOTM Airborne and Utility Task Vehicle) of the Networking on the Move systems.
Networking on the Move (NOTM): $79.373M ($79.359M Active, $0.014M Reserve) - The decrease of $13.296M from FY19 to FY20 is based on the procurement schedule for the NOTM-GCV and completion of the NOTM-A. FY20 funding will procure NOTM GCV systems, NOTM-A modification kits and NOTM UTV systems. FY20 funding will also support acquisition, fielding, and training requirements associated with production systems.
Global Command and Control System - Tactical Combat Operations (GCCS-TCO): $1.409M Active - The increase of $1.029M from FY19 to FY20 will fund technical refresh to align with the procurement schedule. FY20 funds will be used to procure Tactical COP Servers (TCS) and Tactical COP Workstations for the replenishment of currently fielded systems due to harsh field environment and obsolescence.
Joint Battle Command - Platform Family of Systems (JBC-P FoS): $8.159M Active - The decrease of $8.897M from FY19 to FY20 reflects the reduction of MFoCS hardware refresh rate of legacy systems and the HW/SW Integration, New Equipment Training, and Fielding Support to other ground platforms. FY20 funding supports JLTV availability and will continue support for items such as, software and hardware integration, hardware refresh, ancillary equipment, NET and field support, and it will procure Mounted Family of Computer Systems (MFoCS). FY20 funding request is in accordance with the JBC-P hardware refresh cyclethat occurs every two years (i.e. FY18, FY20).
Combat Operations Center (COC): $8.440M ($6.256M Active, $2.184M Reserves) - Increase of $2.672M from FY19 to FY20 will support refresh procurement. FY20 funds will be required for hardware refresh activities in support of a common hardware baseline. Funding will also be used to align the COC software and hardware baseline with systems currently hosted within the COC in order to manage software growth and interoperability. Supporting the existing software baseline is necessary to maintain Authority To Operate (ATO) and integration with Tactical Service Oriented Architecture (TSOA), Joint Tactical Command Operational Picture (COP) Workstation (JTCW), and Command and Control Personal Computer (C2PC).
Handheld Command and Control (H2C2): $11.516M Active - The increase of $11.516M from FY19 to FY20 procures 1250 systems required to maintain Command and Control while operating in austere environments. FY20 funds will procure the Dismounted Handheld Systems. Prior to FY20 the H2C2 effort was captured under the JBCP-FoS Handheld End User Device Early Capability Release.
OCO: FY2018 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: $5.777M
Advanced Field Artillery Tactical Data Systems (AFATDS): $0.177M - FY18 OCO funds will procure replacement assets pulled from artillery units to be prepositioned on ships.
Networking on the Move (NOTM): $5.600M - FY18 OCO will support NOTM systems equipment procurement.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
This budget line item procures radios, radio systems, satellite communications systems, and associated equipment.
Global Broadcast Service (GBS): GBS is a smart-push/user-pull Satellite Communication (SATCOM) system that provides large volumes of information to deployed, or garrison forces. The AN/TSR-9 and AN/TSR-11 receives and disseminates GBS broadcasts at up to 45 Mbps, and is capable of processing both classified and unclassified information products such as: imagery, intelligence, video (NTSC and Digital), theater message traffic, Joint and service-unique news, weather and MWR programming. Each Transportable Ground Receive Suite (TGRS) consists of a Receive Terminal (including a 1-meter parabolic dish antenna), Receive Broadcast Manager Server, Power Controller Unit, Crypto Device (KG-250), Integrated Receiver-Decoder (for NTSC video), Managed Ethernet Switch, Unmanaged Ethernet Switch, Video Converter, and transit cases. The Portable Receive Suite (PRS) is a man-portable ground station single enclave (Classified or Unclassified) receive suite. The PRS can be connected to a LAN with the addition of a user supplied Ethernet switch. The PRS receives information products broadcasted through the Global Broadcast Service (GBS) via the Ka-band transponders via the Wideband Global SATCOM (WGS) satellites' Ka-band downlink transponders.
Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT): The VSAT Family of Systems (FoS) provides wideband, beyond-line-of-sight (BLOS), low-cost satellite communications to Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) commanders from the Major Subordinate Command to Battalion levels. The VSAT FoS provides the RF communications link in support of the transfer of voice, video, and data services.
Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T): SMART-T provides tactical users with protected data and voice via Advanced Extremely High Frequency (AEHF) satellite communications. The SMART-T system is transported on High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicles (HMMWVs), providing MAGTF Commanders a secure, survivable, long-haul, low/medium data rate communications link not subject to terrain masking and horizon limitations. The SMART-T is the only USMC asset that possesses a SATCOM AEHF capability.
Military Global Positioning System (GPS) User Equipment (MGUE) (formerly DAGR): The MGUE is a small-form-factor or handheld receiver that is a self-contained device capable of independently providing the user or external system interface, with positioning, velocity, navigation, and precise time information derived from the GPS precise positioning service (PPS). MGUE activities incorporate incremental approach to meet requirements. Increment I focuses on integration of GPS capabilities into Ground Platforms and Increment II focuses on the next generation Handheld (DAGR) replacement. These increments are phased across the FYDP with Inc I occurring FY17-21 and Inc II occurring FY21-25.
Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM): TCM addresses the requirements to enhance, replace, and sustain tactical radios while achieving interoperability and minimizing the affects of equipment obsolescence. TCM enables Command and Control (C2) and situational awareness at all echelons and elements of the MAGTF. TCM provides for Line of Sight (LOS), Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) secure voice, and data, operating in frequency bands from 1.6MHz to 2.5GHz. TCM procurements enable joint interoperability, mobile networking, and support National Security Agency (NSA) Communications Security (COMSEC) Modernization requirements down to the squad level.
Terrestrial Wideband Transmission Systems (TWTS): TWTS is a capabilities portfolio that provides the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) with a continued capability of secure terrestrial digital data transmission. The portfolio includes, the Army/Navy Transportable Radio Communications-170A (AN/TRC-170A) Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) systems and their replacement Next Generation Troposcatter (NGT). The AN/MRC-142 and the Wireless Point to Point Link (WPPL) Line of Sight (LOS) systems and their replacement called the LOS Replacement (LOS-R), Tactical Elevated Antenna Mast (TEAMS), and Free-Space Optics (FSO) system. The NGT capability will provide a high bandwidth communications data link to support remote locations where satellite communication is not available. The LOS-R capability will provide a digital wideband full duplex link between operating units ashore and units aboard amphibious ships via the Navy's Automated Data Network System (ADNS) to meet ship-to-shore and shore-to-shore communication requirements. FSO is designed to provide additional LOS transmission diversity with an optical line-of-sight transmission path with a Low Probability of Detection/Low Probability of Intercept (LPD/LPI).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY2018 Base Appropriation Request: $28.361M
Global Broadcast Service (GBS): $.990M - Funding procured hardware to support planned tech refresh efforts.
Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT): $7.044($2.454M Base; $4.590M OCO) - Base funding enabled the procurement and integration of the VSAT-L external antenna effort, and refresh and upgrade of components which are end-of-life/end-of-support such as server upgrades; as well as fielding and program support. OCO funding procured an additional (10) VSAT-E Rapid Response Kits (RRKs) to support High Demand/Low Density equipment employed by forward units to include the Special Purpose-Marine Air Ground Task Forces, Marine Expeditionary Units, and Marine Expeditionary Brigades.
Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T): $.549M - Funding allocated to procure tech refresh components, such as electro actuator, elevation motor, and transceiver, to mitigate end of life/end of sale and obsolescence issues until NEXGEN AEHF solution is identified.
Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM): $19.718M - Funding provided for the procurement of Mobile User Objective System (MUOS) capability to include antennas, procurement of Application Program Set (APS) to support TCM's family of systems (FoS) maintenance, and additional ancillary components and program support.
Terrestrial Wideband Transmission Systems (TWTS): $.060M - Funding procured Program Office Management Support. PB19 to PB20 change resulted from delays in Next Generation Tropo development and subsequent acquisition strategy change to award a Marine Corps contract.
FY2019 Base Appropriation Request: $251.412M
Global Broadcast Service (GBS): $1.815M - Funding procures planned hardware tech refresh efforts to mitigate obsolescence issues. Increase of $.825M from FY18 to FY19 will support tech refresh efforts such as crypto modernization.
Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT): $7.567M - Funding provides for system tech refreshes and upgrades to continue mitigation of end-of-life/end-of-support and obsolescence issues; and program support. Increase of $5.113M from FY18 to FY19 will support procurement and integration of tech refresh components such as the Master Reference Terminal (MRT), servers, and switches.
Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T): $.571M - Funding allocated to procure tech refresh components, such as digital transmitter, convertors, and synthesizers, to mitigate end of life/end of sale and obsolescence issues until NEXGEN AEHF solution is identified. Funding also provided for program support.
Military Global Positioning System (GPS) User Equipment (MGUE): $.531M - Funding supports transition from DAGR to MGUE adding the capability of M-Code. Increase of $.531M from FY18 to FY19 reflects the procurement of MGUE, procurement of ancillary components, and program support.
Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM): $204.285M - Funds continue to provide for procurement of multiple families of radio systems which support the primary voice and data communication requirements for the operational forces, fielding requirements, and program support. Increase of $184.567M will support completion of the MUOS FW and MUOS antenna procurements, procurement of High Frequency Radio II (HFR II) capabilities ($116.342M), and initial Multi-Channel Man Pack (MCMP) capabilities ($7.500M). The MUOS FW capability and MUOS antennas ($75.020M)replaces aging Ultra High Frequency (UHF) tactical satellite capabilities. HFR II replaces aging legacy HFR radios to meet the National Security Agency (NSA) mandate for Communications Security (COMSEC) modernization with approved cryptopgraphic products. MCMP replaces legacy single channel radios which do not currently provide ultra high-frequency SATCOM capability and are required to be replaced due to the NSA mandate for COMSEC modernization. Remaining funds ($5.423M)support ancillary components and program production and fielding support.
Terrestrial Wideband Transmission System (TWTS): $36.643M - Funding supports procurement of 30 NGT assets ($36M) and system data. NGT replaces the AN/TRC 170A system that is facing severe diminishing manufacturing sources and material shortages (DMSMS) and will provide a C and X band alternative satellite communication frequencies. PB19 to PB20 changes resulted from an acquisition strategy change. The program was initially structured to procure C band systems from an Army contract and X band system from a USMC contract; however, the Army's systems did not meet the USMC requirements. Therefore the program was restructured to procure a combined C and X band solution via one contract in order to meet USMC requirements. In addition, funds ($.643M) will fund program support. Increase from FY19 to FY20 supports procurement of 30 NGT systems and program support efforts.
FY2020 Base Appropriation Request: $227.320M
Global Broadcast Service (GBS): $1.764M - Funding will procure hardware to support planned tech refresh efforts and programmatic support. Decrease of $0.049M from FY2019 to FY2020 is due to the completion of crypto modernization.
Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT): $15.957M - Funding will enable the procurement of 42 VSAT-Medium Refresh terminals and spares which will replace the legacy VSAT-M terminals to address obsolescence issues and programmatic support. Increase of $8.392M from FY19 to FY20 will support procurement of the terminals, and the production of logistics and engineering products.
Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T): $.000M - Decrease from FY19 to FY20 of $0.571 reflects the elimination of funding to better align with the National Defense Strategy.
Military Global Positioning System (GPS) User Equipment (MGUE): $7.965M - Funding will support transition from DAGR to MGUE, adding to the M-Code capability. Increase of $7.434M from FY19 to FY20 reflects initial procurement of Increment I cards to integrate into various platforms, procurement of ancillary components, and program support.
Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM): $164.165M - Funding will continue to provide for the procurement of multiple families of radio systems which support the primary voice and data communication requirements for the operational forces. Funding will support procurement of High Frequency Radio II (HFR II) capabilities, Multi-Channel Man Pack (MCMP) capabilities, Multi-Channel Handheld (MCHH) capabilities and spares for radio systems, fielding support, and other ancillaries. HFR II replaces aging legacy HFR radios to meet the National Security Agency (NSA) mandate for Communications Security (COMSEC) modernization with approved cryptographic products. Multi-Channel Radio family of systems (MCR FoS), MCMP and MCHH, replaces legacy single channel radios that do not meet the NSA mandate for COMSEC modernization. Decrease of $40.120M due to completion of MBR II MUOS procurement. CE.5.6. unit cost increase of $5k from FY19 to FY20 is due to the cost estimate for MCMP and additional capabilities e.g. Waveforms. The quantity increase from FY19 to FY20 is due to the planned schedule procurement of MCMP AAO completion in FY20.
Terrestrial Wideband Transmission System (TWTS): $37.469M - Funding supports procurement of LOS-R radios, ancillary components, and masts as well as engineering and program support for the TWTS portfolio. The LOS-R radio procurement enables the Marine Corps to mitigate sustainment issues and readiness concerns due to component obsolescence and end-of-life/end-of-sale (EOL/EOS) of the AN/MRC-142 and WPPL-T. The LOS-R system ensures interoperability with the Navy and is compatible with the Army's TRILOS system. Increase of $.826M from FY19 to FY20 supports LOS-R program initiation shift from FY19 to FY20.
