proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Communications Security (COMSEC): COMSEC is the USMC Commodities Management Office (CMO) providing support for installations and designated acquisition program COMSEC requirements, intermediate logistics, and configuration management. COMSEC provides support for Protected Secure Voice and Data transmissions, the Electronic Key Management Systems (EKMS) transition to the Key Management Infrastructure (KMI), the National Security Agency (NSA) directed Cryptographic Modernization of the COMSEC infrastructure, Installations (base, posts, and station), and platforms. CMO ensures the protection of Marine Corps and Joint cyberspace systems from exploitation and attack. Cyberspace systems include wired and wireless telecommunications systems, Information Technology (IT) systems, and the content processed, stored, or transmitted therein. Rapid changes in the underlying commercial and government cyber infrastructures makes cyber security an increasingly complex and dynamic problem. CMO provides the Warfighter the essential information trust characteristics of availability, confidentiality, integrity, authentication, and non-repudiation.
Joint Communications Support Element (JCSE): Joint Communications Support Element (JCSE), headquartered at MacDill Air Force Base, Fla., rapidly delivers secure, reliable, and scalable command, control, communications, and computer capabilities (C4) ranging from small mobile team missions to full Joint task force headquarters (JTF HQ) deployments.
Combat Data Network (CDN) (formerly Tactical Data Network (TDN) Data Distribution System - Modular (DDS-M)): The CDN provides the commander a modular, integrated, and interoperable Internet Protocol (IP) - based LAN and WAN data networking capability that forms the data communications backbone and data communications support to organizations within a Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF). The CDN provides an extension of the Defense Information System Network (DISN), Secret Internet Protocol Router Network (SIPRNet), Sensitive But Unclassified (SBU), Non-secure Internet Protocol Router Network (NIPRNet) as well as a Coalition networking capability and access to strategic, supporting establishments, Joint, and other service component tactical data networks for Marine Corps Tactical Data Systems (TDSs) and other DDS-Ms. The CDN provides Marine Corps maneuver elements with a modular and scalable IP data transport capability that will replace, supplement, and be used with existing legacy data systems through the integration of computers, routers, data switches and cabling, Enhanced Position Location and Reporting System (EPLRS) radio net interface units, modems, link encryption devices, and patch panels. Uninterrupted Power Supplies (UPS) provide for emergency power and continuity of operations. The CDN can operate from the SBU up to the Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information (TS/SCI) level and contains integral In-line Network Encryption (INE) device supporting IP Security (IPSec) and Virtual Private Networking (VPN).
Tactical Voice Switching System (TVSS): The TVSS is a modular Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) circuit switch capable system that combines voice and Voice Over Internet Protocol telecommunications, multiplexing, transmission encryption, and group modem capabilities in one system for command, control, administrative, and logistic voice communications. It facilitates secure and non-secure voice, circuit switching functions, and network routing and management functions with current fielded tactical systems of the military services. It is interoperable with Joint, coalition, host nation networks, and it operates in unclassified and classified environments.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY2018 Base Appropriation Request: $38.864M
COMSEC: $1.163M. ($0.908M Active, $0.255M Reserve). Funding continued procurement of COMSEC modernization items such as replacement of damaged COMSEC equipment and ancillary devices.
JCSE: $0.474M Active. FY2018 funds reflected the Marine Corps mandated share of efforts to keep the JCSE equipped with the latest state-of-the-art equipment to accomplish its Joint Staff Mission. FY18 funding procured cryptographic equipment in support of the Joint Staff Mission.
CDN: $37.128M ($34.943M Active, $2.185M Reserves). FY2018 funds supported Engineering Change Proposals, procurement, and fielding for the CDN networking equipment technology refresh to include the procurement of Small Form Factor items to reduce size, weight, and power (SWaP) requirements of the CDN systems. Funds also supported management, acquisition, logistics, manpower support, Personnel and Training Analysis, and Training Plan development and support.
TVSS: $0.099M Active. FY2018 funds supported equipment training for the added video teleconference equipment and modifications to TVSS systems that ensure viable voice communication capability for all echelons of the MAGTF.
FY2019 Base Appropriation Request: $31.175M
COMSEC: $0.324M ($0.066M Active, $0.258M Reserve). Decrease of $0.839M from FY2018 to FY2019 reflects restructure of COMSEC modernization in support of Expeditionary Force 21 and National Security Agency guidelines. Funding provides for procurements to replace damaged COMSEC equipment, and ancillary devices.
JCSE: $0.481M Active. Increase of $0.007M from FY2018 to FY2019 reflects the Marine Corps mandated share of efforts to keep the JCSE equipped with the latest state-of-the-art equipment to accomplish its Joint Staff Mission. The specific purpose will be determined at the annual JCSE modernization review.
CDN: $30.370M ($28.180M Active, $2.190M Reserves). Decrease of $6.763M from FY2018 to FY2019 reflects Network Optimization of Information Assurance Modules activities moving from procurement to operations and maintenance. FY19 funds will support technology refresh Engineering Change Proposals, procurement, and fielding for various CDN equipment. 3.1 Program Spt/Fielding/CLS/Training funds will support management, acquisition, logistics, manpower support, personnel, and training analysis as well as training plan development and associated support. 3.3 ECP Network Equipment funds will support procurement of the Local Area Network (LAN) Services Module (Routers). 3.4 Small Form Factor funds will support procurement of additional quantities of Small Form Factor to reduce size, weight, and power (SWaP). 3.9 ECP Network Equipment funds will support procurement of the Local Area Network (LAN) Services Module (Routers) for Reserve Units. 3.10 Small Form Factor (Reserve) funds will support procurement of additional quantities of Small Form Factor to reduce size, weight, and power (SWaP) for Reserve Units.
FY2020 Base Appropriation Request: $31.685M
The FY2020 funding request increased by $.510M largely due to Combat Data Network (CDN) Reserve funding increase.
COMSEC: $1.250M ($0.987M Active, $0.263M Reserves). Increase of $0.926M from FY2019 to FY2020 reflects continued COMSEC modernization and Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) upgrades to currently fielded assets, in support of Expeditionary Force 21 and National Security Agency guidelines. Funding will continue to procure replacements for damaged COMSEC equipment, ancillary devices, and program support for product verification/validation testing.
JCSE: $0.491M Active. Increase of $0.010M from FY2019 to FY2020 reflects the Marine Corps mandated share of efforts to keep the JCSE equipped with the latest state-of-the-art equipment to accomplish its Joint Staff Mission. The specific purpose will be determined at the annual JCSE modernization review.
CDN: $29.944M ($25.708M Active, $4.236M Reserves). Decrease of $0.426M from FY2019 to FY2020 reflects the completion of Small Form Factor procurement engineering activities. FY20 funds will support technology refresh Engineering Change Proposals, procurement, and fielding for various parts of the CDN equipment family. The Small Form Factor activities in FY20 are the execution of material optional contract line items based on FY19 procurement engineering effort. Small Form Factor funds (active/reserve) will support procurement of additional quantities of Small Form Factor to reduce size, weight, and power (SWaP). ECP Network Equipment funds will support procurement of the Wide Area Network (WAN) Services Module (Routers) hardware. ECP Network Equipment (Reserves) funds will support procurement of hardware in support of the technology refresh cycle, this upgrades equipment every three to five years.

proc:Name.footnote: COMSEC: Increase of $.445 from FY19 to FY20 provides for support to perform validation and verification on crypto modernization, in accordance with National Security mandates, prior to equipment being issued.

COMSEC: Hardware $.476M increase from FY19 to FY20 aligns to procurement schedule. Total increase increase of $.476 supports procurements and replacements of damaged COMSEC equipment and ancillary devices.
CDN: Program Spt/Fielding/CLS/Training decrease of $0.926M from FY19 to FY20 reflects Small Form Factor activities moving from procurement to operations and maintenance.

CDN systems consist of multiple components with various quantities and prices obscuring individual pricing. CDN: ECP Network Equipment decrease of $9.450M from FY19 to FY20 reflects completion of Local Area Network (LAN) Services Module (Routers) refresh in FY19. FY20 Network Equipment of $5.818M is a separate Routers activity that will be a tech refresh for the Wide Area Network (WAN) Services Module.

CDN: ECP Small Form Factor increase of $7.904M from FY19 to FY20 reflects the reprioritization of FY19 funds to the Local Area Network (LAN) Services Module (Routers) hardware refresh. Additionally, the delay in the initial award of Small Form Factor contract until 1QFY19 pushed additional funding to FY20. The Small Form Factor effort does not change, procurement of remaining Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO) will occur in FY20.
CDN: ECP Network Equipment (Reserves) decrease of $0.144M from FY19 to FY20 reflects completion of Wide Area Network (WAN) Services Module (Routers) hardware refresh.

CDN systems consist of multiple components with various quantities and prices obscuring individual pricing. CDN: ECP Small Form Factor (Reserves) increase of $2.190M from FY19 to FY20 reflects the reprioritization of the FY19 funds to the Local Area Network (LAN) Services Module (Routers) hardware refresh. The Small Form Factor effort does not change, but the additional procurements will not happen until FY20.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
BASE TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE (BTI) provides all Marine Corps installations with the base area network communications infrastructure that connects the end-user to the DISA network. BTI modernizes, sustains, upgrades and enhances the telecommunications systems infrastructure for all Marine Corps Installations in order to meet the demands required to support the 5th Element of the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF). BTI is designed to maintain current industry standards as they relate to technological capabilities for all voice, video and data services (both wired and wireless connections) and are transported via each installation's infrastructure. These data services include, support for but are not limited to, Enhanced 911 (E911), Video-Teleconferencing, Integrated Services Digital Network, Marine Corps Enterprise Network, Energy Monitoring Control Systems, Intrusion Detection Systems, Access Control Systems, Fire Alarm Control Networks and Fleet Training Systems. This includes supporting systems such as optical networks, telecommunications management systems, primary power, voice mail, teleconferencing, and outside plant infrastructure. The ongoing focus is technology refresh and standardization on DISA Unified Capabilities (UC) (voice, video, collaboration, and data) through modernization of installation infrastructure in order to maintain connection to the DISA network. This line item includes funding specified for Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI) within the above details.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI) is a framework of laws, policies, procedures, and technologies for the use of digital credentials, which provide confidentiality, integrity, authenticity, and non-repudiation in electronic communications and transactions. PKI allows secure access to IT systems. PKI has the ability to electronically sign documents, encrypt messages and documents, and to authenticate and protect web access... In compliance with DOD policy and direction, the USMC Public Key Infrastructure Program (PKI) program provides the resources, manpower and equipment (hardware and software), dedicated to the management (i.e.: generation, production, distribution, control, accounting and destruction) of keys and certificates used by public key-based security services to include NIPRNet and SIPRNet both garrison and deployed. The PKI program operates the USMC Certificate Validation Infrastructure necessary to ensure that only authorized users and server based applications are allowed to operate on the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN). These services are required for user access to all information system components on the MCEN including network accounts, applications and web sites. PKI must be operable in garrison and tactical/deployed environments. Beginning in FY20, PKI was transferred to a new procurement line item, 4645 Cyberspace Activities, in order to consolidate Marine Corps Cyberspace Procurement Activities into one LI.
CONSOLIDATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM (CERS) is a centrally managed program to field a technology solution in support of emergency dispatch personnel that facilitates timely responses when emergency calls for service are received. CERS provides command and coordination dispatch functions for first responders to support All-Hazard missions. It standardizes Emergency Dispatch Centers to provide notification functions, resource management and situational awareness in order to increase efficient emergency and day-to-day first responder operations. CERS capability is achieved through delivery of Enhanced 911 (E911) and emergency dispatch capabilities consisting of Computer Aided Dispatch (CAD), Fire Station Alerting (FSA) and Mobile Data Computers (MDC) for first responder's vehicles.
ENTERPRISE LAND MOBILE RADIOS (E-LMR) is a modern, digital, Association of Public Safety Communications Officials Project 25 Trunked radio system at all Marine Corps Bases, Posts and Stations (BPS). It provides the wireless Radio Frequency (RF) communications that are required to support the Consolidated Emergency Response System and First Responders (i.e. Police, Fire, Emergency Medical Services) as part of the Emergency Management Command and Coordination initiative. Specifically, the radio system provides RF coverage to BPS populated areas and roads in-between, permitting positive command and coordination between Dispatchers and First Responders and enables their ability to respond to incidents during normal, crisis, and recovery operations. In the wake of 9/11 and the Ft. Hood incident, DoD recognized that effective emergency communications and mutual aid support operation are key elements in providing homeland security, reducing the loss of life and the preservation of property. Thus, the objective for the E-LMR acquisition is to bring forth a reliable interoperability wireless communication system with a limited data capability. This line item includes funding specified for Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI) within the above details.
TEST, EVALUATION, & ENGINEER ENVIRONMENT (TE&EE) is a Marine Corps Tactical Systems Support Activity (MCTSSA) provides the only Marine Corps organic, operationally relevant, MAGTF Command, Control, Communications, Computers, and Intelligence (C4I) architecture for testing and engineering tasks. This environment is the sole organic solution in the Marine Corps for Link-16 Tactical Data Link Networks for air-to- air, ship, and shore targeting and messaging, validated at MCTSSA before Marine/Navy use in theater. The environment also provides Marine Corps organic equipment, environments, operators, and testers for Joint Communications Exercises, Joint Interoperability Testing, and Systems of System testing. Funding supports modernization and expansion of the MAGTF Systems Integration Environment at MCTSSA for non-Table of Equipment items: Communications Backbone, Test Tool/Data Collection Hardware/Software, and Computers. The environment is essential to operating forces support for fielded C4I systems, as well as evaluating USMC and Joint C4I systems in a controlled, repeatable, and re-configurable manner that reduces program risk and identifies significant deficiencies prior to fielding to the operating forces. More than forty Marine Corps C4I programs and systems rely on MCTSSA support.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATIONS PROGRAM (MCIOP) provides MAGTF commanders and the Marine Corps a responsive and effective full-spectrum information operations (IO) planning and psychological operations delivery capability by means of deployable support teams and a comprehensive general support IO reach-back capability in order to integrate IO into Marine Corps operations. Multiple classification levels require separate Information Technology (IT) infrastructure to support each classification level in accordance with National Security Agency and Defense Intelligence Agency standards. This includes equipment necessary for connecting internal MCIOC IT infrastructure (voice, video, and data) with the existing Marine Corps Base Quantico support infrastructure.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2018 Justifications: $36.114M
BASE TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE (BTI) $26.152M:
$3.369M will support DPRI. FY18 funding is required to install base telecommunications infrastructure for two Japanese funded MILCON projects in Guam. These projects will establish a non-live fire training area in Andersen South and a waterfront headquarters facility in Apra Harbor. The Andersen South training facility will provide Marines with the ability to maintain readiness by conducting convoys, military operations on urbanized terrain, and breaching. The waterfront headquarters facility is required for the mobilization and de-mobilization of cargo and personnel in/out of Guam. These requirements are directly related to the relocation of Marines from Okinawa to Guam. The funding decrease of $4.360M from FY 2017 to FY 2018 is due to the alignment of the DPRI BTI installation schedule with the Guam construction schedule.
$22.783M will support the technology refresh and standardization of DISA Unified Capabilities (voice, video, collaboration, and data) through UC/DWDM modernization at two Marine Corps installations. The funding increase of $13.582M from FY 2017 to FY 2018 is due to the increase in the number of installations receiving the UC/DWDM upgrade.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI): $0.209M funding supported the continuation of PKI hardware and software implementation across the NIPRNet and SIPRNet for both garrison and deployed networks in order to meet CYBERCOM's Tasking Order requiring the use of hardware tokens for access to networks, network resources, and secure email in accordance with DODI 8520.02 and DODI 8520.03. Funding was utilized to procure necessary tokens and equipment for SIPRNet Token issuance across the MCEN as well as implementation of the DOD PKI NIPRNet Enterprise Alternate Token Management System.
CONSOLIDATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM (CERS): $4.709M supported network connection, procurement, and fielding of emergency dispatch systems. This requirement is necessary to provide effective Public Safety Communications and notifications to emergency responders. If not funded this will affect USMC's ability to provide effective emergency response.
ENTERPRISE LAND MOBILE RADIOS (E-LMR): $3.872M funding supported the completion of E-LMR Western Region Infrastructure contract to include network connection and implementation at Marine Corps Mountain Warfare Training Center-Bridgeport (MWTC).
TEST, EVALUATION, & ENGINEERING ENVIRONMENT - EQUIPMENT & TECHNICAL SERVICES (TEEE): $0.921M Funding supported the maintenance and expansion of the MAGTF Systems Integration Environment at MCTSSA for non-Table of Equipment Items: Communications Backbone, Test Tool/Data Collection Hardware/Software, and Computers. Realignment of effort to new BLI 4620 in FY19 and beyond reflects USMC Program Management Office (PMO) reorganization to improve support of USMC OPFOR.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATIONS PROGRAM (MCIOP): $0.251M Funding is for the refresh of hardware required on both the classified Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communications System (JWICS) and unclassified Open Source Information System (OSIS) networks. JWICS and OSIS are both provided by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) through Marine Corps Intelligence Activity (MCIA). JWICS provides MCIOC with classified network connectivity and OSIS provides MCIOC with unclassified network connectivity.
FY 2019 Justifications: $72.842M
Beginning in FY19, MCIOP and TEEE funding has been realigned from BLI 4635 COMM & ELEC INFRASTRUCTURE SUPT, to BLI 4620, ITEMS UNDER $5 MILLION (COMM & ELEC).
BASE TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE (BTI) $45.720M:
DPRI - $22.001M FY 2019 funding, executed by Space and Naval Warfare Center (SPAWAR), will procure, install, and accredit, Information Technology (IT) systems. The scope of the work will support the ongoing eight MILCON projects. There are two Japanese funded MILCON projects (J-007 Waterfront HQ and J-755 Urban Combat Trng) and six U.S. funded MILCON projects (P-250 MALS Fac, P-260 Corrosion Ctrl Hangar, P-270 ACE Gym & Dining, P-295 Ordnance Ops, P-601 Aircraft Maintenance #2, and P-715 KD Ranges). The IT systems are integral to making the facilities complete and useable. All projects are vital to supporting the relocation of Marines from Okinawa to Guam. Cost Element 1.1 funding increase of $18.632M from FY 2018 to FY 2019 is due to the alignment of the DPRI BTI installation schedule with the Guam construction schedule.
UC/DWDM - $23.719M supports the technology refresh and standardization of DISA Unified Capabilities (voice, video, collaboration, and data) through UC/DWDM modernization at two Marine Corps installations. Modernization and upgrade of the network telecommunications infrastructure is necessary to ensure the delivery of voice, video, and data services that support the day-to-day operations of the Base, Post, and Station. Cost Element 1.2 funding increase of $0.936M from FY 2018 to FY 2019 is due to the increased size and scope of the installations receiving the UC/DWDM upgrade.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI): $.119M funding supports the continuation of PKI hardware and software implementation across the (NIPRNet and SIPRNet) for both garrison and deployed networks in order to meet CYBERCOM's Tasking Order requiring the use of hardware tokens for access to networks, network resources and secure email in accordance with DODI 8520.02 and DODI 8520.03. Funding will also be utilized to procure necessary tokens and equipment for SIPRNet Token issuance across the MCEN as well as implementation of the DOD PKI NIPRNet Enterprise Alternate Token Management System.
CONSOLIDATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM (CERS): $8.391M supports technical refresh engineering of emergency dispatch systems and system hardware/software upgrade. Includes system release upgrades, technical refresh planning, and recurring evaluation to ensure the full scope of CERS systems perform as designed; develop engineering and technical improvements to enhance the reliability, maintainability, safety, and effectiveness of the fielded systems; and periodical verification of compatibility with other non-ERS fielded systems. The increase from $4.709M in FY 2018 to $8.391M in FY 2019 is due to the Marine Corps' decision to allocate additional funding to the CERS program in order to support the DoD CIO's Windows 10 mandate. The inability to comply with the DoD Windows 10 mandate could prevent the first responder's ability to communicate and respond effectively to emergency situations increasing the chance of loss of life.
ENTERPRISE LAND MOBILE RADIOS (E-LMR): $13.485M funding supports multi-band radio (MBR) technical refresh and associated fielding support as well as system hardware/software upgrade. The increase from $3.872M in FY 2018 to $13.485M in FY 2019 due the Marine Corps' decision to allocate additional funding to the CERS program in order to support the DoD CIO Windows 10 mandate and planned tech refresh for first responder multiband radios (MBR).
DPRI $5.127M funding supports DPRI Guam requirements for ELMR capability expansion from 10 GTR channels to 20 GTR channels in support of P-715 Live Fire Training Range Complex project for the planned build-up of USMC personnel at Northwest Field to Finegayan (future MCB Guam). It will also increase two way radio usage on the Joint Regional Marianas (JRM) ELMR System's Ritidian site and max-out the site's capacity.
FY 2020 Justifications: $21.140M
BASE TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE (BTI) $14.897M
DPRI (Cost Element 1.1), funding supports DPRI Okinawa Telecom infrastructure supporting internal and external communications. Projects include MC0508: Base Communications Building, MC0512-T: Theater, MC0512-T-E: 4 BEQs.
Unified Capabilities/Dense Wave Division Multiplexing (Cost Element 1.2) funding will provide for the upgrade and standardization of DISA Unified Capabilities (voice, video, collaboration, and data) through UC/DWDM modernization at one Marine Corps Installation. Modernization and upgrade of the Installation's transport infrastructure is necessary to ensure the delivery of voice, video, and data services that support the day-to-day operations of the Base, Post, and Station. This modernized transport capability provides for the underlying infrastructure supporting transformational requirements identified in the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control strategy (i.e. migration to the cloud, modernizing the network). These modernizations to the transport infrastructure are required to avoid severe degradation and potential loss of voice, video, and data services, jeopardizing Base operations, unit coordination and critical life safety services.
FY19 to FY20 funding decreased from $45.720M to $14.897M, a $30.823M decrease due to the difference in scope and complexity of the modernization efforts, reduction in cost estimates, and construction schedule delays in Guam.
CONSOLIDATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM (CERS): $1.958M
Tech Refresh Modernization (Cost Element 2.1) funding increased from $0.000M in FY 2019 to $1.000M in FY 2020 due to the start of technical refresh modernization. This effort provides for the modernization of the E911 system to ensure that the components in the current system do not become end of life and unsupported by the vendor. If the aging, end of life equipment is not replaced, then these aging network devices will be removed from the network as a result of not receiving cybersecurity updates which will lead to the Consolidated Emergency Response System being unable to operate which will significantly degrade the first responder's ability to respond to emergency situations in a timely manner.
Tech Refresh Engineering (Cost Element 2.2) funding decreased from $2.091M in FY 2019 to $0.958M in FY 2020, a $1.133M decrease, due to the planned completion of technical refresh engineering in FY 2020 as technical refresh modernization and initial hardware procurement begins in FY 2020.
Engineering Change Proposal (Cost Element 2.8) funding decreased from $6.300M in FY 2019 to $0.00M in FY 2020, a $6.300M decrease, due to the completion of the mandated Windows 10 upgrade in FY 2019.
ENTERPRISE LAND MOBILE RADIOS (E-LMR): $4.285M
Subscriber Units Multi-Band Radios (MBRs) Refresh (Cost Element 4.1) funding decreased from $6.705M in FY 2019 to $3.207M in FY 2020, a $3.498M decrease, due to the reduced MBR refresh requirement in FY 2020. Funding in this cost element supports the continued replacement of MBRs which are becoming end of life and unsupported by the vendor. If this equipment is not replaced then these antiquated end of life mobile radios would prevent USMC First Responders and Range and Training Area personnel from achieving operational mission support to protect life and property on USMC Installations.
Fielding Activities (Cost Element 4.6) funding decreased from $1.880M in FY 2019 to $1.045M in FY 2020, a $0.835M decrease, due to the reduction of Multi-Band Radio fielding in FY 2020. E-LMR funding will support the fielding activities associated with the multi-band radio (MBR) technical refresh which replaced end of life mobile radios. This cost element directly supports Cost Element 4.1
Engineering Change Proposal (Cost Element 4.7) funding decreased from $4.900M in FY 2019 to $0.000M in FY 2020, a $4.900M decrease, due to planned completion of the mandated system hardware/software upgrade in FY 2019.
E-LMR DPRI (Cost Element 4.8): $0.033M - FY20 Funding is required to procure equipment to expand the current ELMR network that supports JRM. JRM provides ELMR support for all DOD and Federal organizations on the island of Guam. ELMR expansion is vital to supporting the relocation of Marines from Okinawa to Guam.

proc:Name.footnote: FY19 to FY20 funding decreased from $45.720M to $14.897M, a $30.823M decrease due to the difference in scope and complexity of the modernization efforts, reduction in cost estimates and construction schedule delays in Guam.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Beginning in FY20, efforts in this line item (LI) were transferred from existing LIs in order to consolidate Marine Corps Cyberspace Procurement Activities into one LI. MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG), and UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS FORCES CYBERSPACE COMMAND (MARFORCYBER) efforts were transferred from LI 4630, Common Computer Resources. PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI) was transferred from LI 4635, Comm and Elec Infrastructure Support.
MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG) will execute Marine Corps Global Information Grid Operations and Marine Corps Defensive Cyber Operations in support of Marine Corps operational requirements in order to enhance freedom of action across all warfighting domains, while denying the efforts of adversaries to degrade or disrupt this advantage through cyberspace. MCCOG is the Network Operations (NETOPS) component of Marine Corps Forces Cyberspace Command and provides network situational awareness, command and control, and technical support to Marine Corps operating forces and supporting establishment organizations, both in garrison and while deployed. MCCOG is the primary DOD Computer Network Defense Service Provider for the U.S. Marine Corps and directs Service actions to prevent and respond to security incidents. The MCCOG delivers numerous enterprise services for the Marine Corps, to include mainframe computer services management, Defense Message System (DMS), DOD Public Key Infrastructure (PKI), and Active Directory/Global Address List. The MCCOG is responsible for the operations and defense of MCEITS, which delivers data center services to the Marine Corps. Finally, MCCOG provides technical expertise to HQMC, Marine Corps Combat Development Command (MCCDC), Marine Corps Systems Command (MCSC), and Marine Corps organizations around the world in support of Information Technology initiatives undertaken within the Marine Corps and DOD. The PMC funding will support Core Competencies in the Computer Networks Defense and Network Ops areas with skilled cyber-warriors (24x7x365). The added responsibilities and network security events have required continued operational employment of current assets and personnel. PMC funding is based on increased mission requirements dictated by DoD/USSTRATCOM/USCYBERCOM Operations to defend the network. The procurement funding will be used to refresh the MCCOG Alternate Network Operations Security Center, USMC Site R refresh, Network Common Operational Picture Tools, Host Based Security Systems, Secure Configuration Compliance Validation Initiative and Secure Configuration Remediation Initiative (SCCVI/SCRI), Intrusion Prevention and scanning tools, Virtual Private Network, and other operations and defense tools.
UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS FORCES CYBERSPACE COMMAND (MARFORCYBER) will procure hardware and software for Deployable Mission Support Systems (DMSS) suites. DMSS Cyber Mission Forces (CMF) weapon system in direct support of global missions. DMSS suites are maintained with hardware support and software renewals, and refresh perpetual software licenses and engineering support. As directed by United States Cyberspace Command (USCC) in FY20 PBD 700A1, MARFORCYBER was directed to man, train and equip a Joint Mission Operation Center (JMOC) at Fort Meade. This is one of four JMOCs in support of United States Cyberspace Command (USCC) and Joint Forces Headquarters Cyber (JFHQ-C) mission.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI) is a framework of laws, policies, procedures, and technologies for the use of digital credentials, which provide confidentiality, integrity, authenticity, and non-repudiation in electronic communications and transactions. PKI allows secure access to IT systems. PKI has the ability to electronically sign documents, encrypt messages and documents, and to authenticate and protect web access... In compliance with DOD policy and direction, the USMC Public Key Infrastructure Program (PKI) program provides the resources, manpower and equipment (hardware and software), dedicated to the management (i.e.: generation, production, distribution, control, accounting and destruction) of keys and certificates used by public key-based security services to include NIPRNet and SIPRNet both garrison and deployed. The PKI program operates the USMC Certificate Validation Infrastructure necessary to ensure that only authorized users and server based applications are allowed to operate on the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN). These services are required for user access to all information system components on the MCEN including network accounts, applications and web sites. PKI must be operable in garrison and tactical/deployed environments.
USMC MAGTF DCO-IDM Suite: The USMC Marine Corps Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) Defensive Cyberspace Operations-Internal Defensive Measures (DCO-IDM) Suite program provides the self-contained, fly-away equipment (hardware and software) for MAGTF DCO-IDM Teams to conduct vulnerability analysis (VA), incident response (IR), and other DCO-IDM functions concurrently on classified and unclassified networks. The teams utilize the interface (a laptop), data from passive and active sensors (servers, laptops, and taps), and the analytic capability from the hardware and software in order to determine the state of the supported commander's network, host, and major weapon systems. Software includes Government Off-the-Shelf (GOTS), Commercial Off-the-Shelf (COTS), and free and open-source software (FOSS). MAGTF DCO Suites are intended to be part of a common family of systems in support of MAGTF cyberspace operations. MAGTF DCO-IDM Suites must be operable in garrison and tactical/deployed environments.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
Beginning in FY20, efforts in this line item (LI) were transferred from existing LIs in order to consolidate Marine Corps Cyberspace Procurement Activities into one LI. MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG), and UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS FORCES CYBERSPACE COMMAND (MARFORCYBER) efforts were transferred from LI 4630, Common Computer Resources. PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI) was transferred from LI 4635, Comm and Elec Infrastructure Support.
FY18 Base Appropriation: $21.111M
MARFORCYBER: FY18 Base Appropriation Request: $20.902M completed MARFORCYBER's headquarters MILCON facility on the East Campus at Fort Meade. It also completed the FY14 MILCON project number P001 items such as Distributed Computing Equipment, Video Teleconferencing and Multi-media Equipment, Network Hardware, Telephone Equipment, Cable Infrastructure, Wireless Center, and Operations Center. In addition it procured hardware and software for Deployable Mission Support Systems (DMSS). DMSS kits are maintained with hardware support, software renewals, and refresh perpetual software licenses. DMSS kits are required in order for MARFORCYBER to support Marine units all across the globe.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI): $0.209M funding supported the continuation of PKI hardware and software implementation across the (NIPRNet and SIPRNet) for both garrison and deployed networks in order to meet CYBERCOM's Tasking Order requiring the use of hardware tokens for access to networks, network resources and secure email in accordance with DODI 8520.02 and DODI 8520.03. Funding will also be utilized to procure necessary tokens and equipment for SIPRNet Token issuance across the MCEN as well as implementation of the DOD PKI NIPRNet Enterprise Alternate Token Management System. FY19 Base Appropriation:
FY19 Base Appropriation: $21.150M
MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG): FY19 Base Appropriation Request: $7.683M procures hardware and software for Defensive Cyber Operations support and network infrastructure upgrades. The increase of $4.455M from FY18 to FY19 is due to increased equipment procurement and technology insertion for defensive cyberspace operations capabilities, Department of Defense Information Network operations, and continuity of operations requirements.
MARFORCYBER: FY19 Base Appropriation Request: $13.348M procures hardware and software for Deployable Mission Support Systems (DMSS). DMSS kits are maintained with hardware support, software renewals, and refresh perpetual software licenses. DMSS kits are required in order for MARFORCYBER to support Marine Corps units all across the globe. $8.488M will procure DMSS for MARFORCYBER and $4.860M will procure DMSS for the Marine Corps Operating Forces. The $4.326M decrease from FY18 to FY19 is a result of the completion of the MARFORCYBER Headquarters Building, FY14 MILCON Project P001.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI): $0.119M funding supports the continuation of PKI hardware and software implementation across the (NIPRNet and SIPRNet) for both garrison and deployed networks in order to meet CYBERCOM's Tasking Order requirement. Funding decrease of $0.090M from FY18 to FY19 is the result of virtualization of tactical hardware and the reclassification of NIPRNet Enterprise Alternate Tokens and SIPRNet Tokens from equipment to consummables.
FY20 Base Appropriation: $27.632M
MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG): FY20 Base Appropriation Request: $7.841M will procure hardware and software for Defensive Cyber Operations Support, remote forensics solutions, and Hunt Deployable suites. The increase of $0.158M will provide technical refresh for the USMC Unified Communications project items such as Distributed Computing Equipment, Video Teleconferencing and Multi-Media Equipment, Network Hardware, Telephone Equipment, and Telepresence Content Server. Prior to FY20 this program was aligned to LI 4630.
MARFORCYBER: FY20 Base Appropriation Request: $14.289M will procure hardware and software for Deployable Mission Support Systems (DMSS). The $0.941M increase from FY19 to FY20 is a result of DMSS suites that are maintained with hardware support, software renewals, and refresh perpetual software licenses. DMSS kits are required in order for MARFORCYBER to provide Marine Corps units all across the globe with cyberspace activity support. $6.800M will procure tools, platforms, infrastructure, and sustainment for various Offensive Cyberspace Operations (OCO) requirements to encourage an appropriate Service-Level analysis for the Joint Mission Operations Center (JMOC) Meade requirement in support of United States Cyberspace Command (USCC) and Joint Forces Headquarters Cyber (JFHQ-c) mission. $4.271M will procure a Defensive Cyberspace Operations War room, Commercial Solutions for Classified (CSfC), engineering, tools, platforms, OCO, DCO infrastructure, and sustainment requirements. Prior to FY20 this program was aligned to LI 4630.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI): FY20 Appropriation Request: $0.502M funding will support the continuation of PKI hardware and software implementation across the (NIPRNet and SIPRNet) for both garrison and deployed networks in order to meet DOD CIO requirement. The $0.383M increase from FY19 to FY20 is a result of Certificate Validate Infrastructure (CVI) component refresh requirement. CVI is required in order for end users to authenticate themselves when signing onto Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) accounts. These services are required for user access to all information system components on the MCEN including network accounts, applications and web sites. PKI must be operable in garrison and tactical/deployed environments. Prior to FY20 this program was aligned to LI 4635.
Prior to FY20 this program was aligned to LI 4635.
USMC MAGTF DCO-IDM Suite: $5.000M will procure MAGTF DCO-IDM Suites for fielding to I, II, & III MEF DCO-IDM Companies and Marine Corps Communications-Electronics School. Previously the Operating Forces utilized the DMSS kits for Defensive Cyberspace Operations. This is a new start in FY20.

proc:Name.footnote: Prior to FY20, DMSS kits were utilized to meet this requirement. Beginning in FY20 USMC Operating Forces will begin procurement of a system that meets their unique requirements; the MAGTF DCO-IDM Suite.

Prior to FY20, DMSS kits were requested in LI 4630, Cost Element 7.1. Increase of $11.071 from FY19 to FY20 is due to Joint Mission Operations Center (JMOC) Meade requirement in support of United States Cyberspace Command (USCC) and Joint Forces Headquarters Cyber (JFHQ-c) mission. Procure Defensive Cyberspace Operations (DCO) War room, Commercial Solutions for Classified (CSfC), engineering, tools, platforms, OCO, DCO infrastructure and sustainment requirements.
Prior to FY20, MCCOG funds were requested in LI 4630, Cost Elements 4.2 and 4.3.
Prior to FY20, PKI funds were requested in LI 4635, Cost Element 3.1.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Commercial Cargo Vehicles - The Commercial Cargo Vehicles program is a centrally managed program for procurement of commercially-available and general purpose vehicles such as heavy and light trucks, special purpose trucks, certain fire department trucks, refuse collection trucks, tanker trucks and all types of trailers. This line also includes P-19 Replacement, which is a tactical firefighting vehicle.
This line item includes funding specified for Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI) within the above details.
Emergency Response Vehicles (ERV) - Replaces firefighting apparatuses for maintaining the minimal installations ERV requirements for structural and airfield operations capabilities throughout the Marine Corps. Additionally, Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI). This requirement is to outfit the new Government of Japan funded J-008 Fire Station for the future Marine Corps Base Guam. Specifically this funding will procure the Command Vehicle, Aerial Ladder Truck, Fire Engine, HAZMAT Rescue Vehicle, and Water Tender.
Commercial Passenger Vehicles (CPV) - CPV is a centrally managed program for the procurement of commercially available vehicles, such as sedans, vans and buses of various sizes. These vehicles are primarily used for passenger transportation on Marine Corps Base Japan, where leases are rarely economical.
P-19 Replacement (P-19R) - is replacing the obsolete A/S32P-19A Crash Fire Rescue fleet in support of expeditionary airfield operations and the supporting establishment. The vehicle is outfitted with advanced fire suppression equipment. It provides rescue and aircraft fire fighting capabilities to permanent and expeditionary airfields throughout the Marine Corps. The P-19 Replacement is employed to fight structural fires in support of base camps and as firefighting support to other elements of the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF), such as ammunition supply points, Petroleum, Oil and Lubricant (POL) distribution points or hazardous material storage facilities.
Marine Security Guard (Vehicles) - Funds the procurement of commercial vehicles for the Marine Security Guard based on the requirements of the particular command and country embassies.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY18 Base Appropriation Request: $56.953M($48.034M Active, $8.919M Reserves)
P-19R - Vehicles - $28.549M ($19.630M Active, $8.919M Reserves) Funds procured vehicles and efforts such as modifications and ECP's. Additionally, programmatic oversight (production/progress reviews) and logistics supportability (e.g., FDT) of those production vehicles is required in support of P-19. Compliance with NFPA-414 is required since it is a KPP. The ordering period for the contract expired May FY18. Funding in FY19 and out reflects P-19R realignment to BLI 5050 to centralize modification funding for USMC tactical vehicles.
Commercial Passenger Vehicles - $5.647M: Funds procured buses capable of transporting 33-60 passengers to provide intra shuttle services for Marine Corps bases in Okinawa. Additionally, vans capable of seating 7-8 passengers, sedans and law enforcement sedans will be procured to replace vehicles that are over-aged for Marine Corps Installations Pacific (MCIPAC). Currently, the commercial passenger fleet for MCIPAC is 11% overage. Not only does the program provide support for operating forces' critical training and logistics missions, it also supports quality of life transportation for service-members and families stationed on Marine Corps Installations. Procurement of passenger vehicles in Japan is critical due to the limited ability to lease these types of vehicles. Funds of $4.7M will procure over-the-snow vehicles (troop carrier, cargo and instructor variants) to replace (21) over-aged BV -206 Small Unit Support Vehicles (SUSV) to safely support training and installation requirements during the winter cycle for the Marine Corps Mountain Warfare Training Center.
Commercial Cargo Vehicles - $10.771M: Funds procured low speed electric vehicles, various types of trailers (specialty, lowbed & flatbed) and trucks (fuel, stake-bed, nurse unit, semi-tractor, sewer maintenance & pickup) necessary to provide support for operating forces' critical training and logistics missions. Equipment being procured for Bases and Stations in California must comply with California Air Resource Board (CARB) to reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the coming decade while improving air quality.
Emergency Response Vehicles - $4.533M: Funds procured fire trucks (pumpers/aerial), rescue trucks, and ambulances for Marine Corps activities and commands. The funds will also procure brush trucks and water extenders to maintain ranges, training areas and facilities on Marine Corps Installations.
Marine Security Guard (Vehicles) - $7.453M - Funds the procurement of commercial vehicles for the Marine Security Guard based on the requirements of the particular command and country embassies.
FY19 Base Appropriation Request: $23.864M. Reduction of $33.089M from FY18 to FY19 is due largely to the P-19 line moving to BLI 5050.
Commercial Passenger Vehicles - $3.643M: Funds will continue to procure buses capable of transporting 33-60 passengers to replace the over-aged buses currently being used to provide intra shuttle services for Marine Corps bases in Okinawa. Additionally, vans capable of seating 7-8 passengers, sedans and law enforcement sedans will be procured to replace over-aged vehicles to better support the operation and mission of Marine Corps Installations Pacific (MCIPAC). This operating force support provides quality of life transportation for service-members and families stationed on Marine Corps Installations. Funds will also be used for the procurement of mission critical passenger vehicles (pickup trucks and passenger vans capable of transporting 7-8 passengers) needed for the recent transition of Townsend Bombing Range from the Georgia Air National Guard to the Marine Corps. The average vehicles are increasingly unreliable and are costly to maintain and negatively impact mission capability.
Commercial Cargo Vehicles - $8.469M: Funds will continue to procure low speed electric vehicles, various types of trailers (specialty, lowbed & flatbed) and trucks (fuel, stake-bed, nurse unit, semi-tractor, sewer maintenance & pickup) necessary for Installations support and to provide support for operating forces' critical training and logistics missions. Additionally, provide lift for combat readiness training, the transportation of equipment in support of deployments and the return of deployed forces. Vehicles being procured for California Bases will comply with California Air Resource Board (CARB) to reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the coming decade while improving air quality. Non-compliance results in fines of $10k per day, per vehicle. Funds will also be used to procure mission critical commercial cargo vehicles (tractor trucks, low-boy trailers, etc.) used to move equipment needed to operate and maintain ranges, training areas, facilities, and fight wild land fires on Marine Corps Installations.
Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI) Guam - Cargo vehicle funds of $1.826M will procure (4) JP-5 fuel trucks required to support Marine Corps aviation operations on the North ramp of Naval Support Activity Andersen Air Force Base.
Emergency Response Vehicles - $3.492M: Funds will procure fire trucks (pumpers/aerial), rescue trucks, and ambulances for Marine Corps activities and commands. The funds will also procure brush trucks and water extenders to maintain ranges, training areas and facilities on Marine Corps Installations.
Marine Security Guard (Vehicles) - $6.434M - Funds the procurement of commercial vehicles for the Marine Security Guard based on the requirements of the particular command and country embassies.
FY20 Base Appropriation Request: $28.913M
Commercial Passenger Vehicles - $4.275M: Funding will continue to recapitalize over-aged buses capable of transporting 33-60 passengers in order to provide safe intra shuttle services for Marine Corps bases in Okinawa. Additionally, vans capable of seating 7-8 passengers, sedans and law enforcement sedans will be procured to replace over-aged vehicles to better support the operation and mission of Marine Corps Installations Pacific (MCIPAC) and provide vehicle transportation primarily used for operational forces on Marine Corps Bases Japan, where the Marine Corps cannot lease these vehicles economically. Replacing these vehicles provide a "right-type" and "right-size" solution to support the operation and mission of the USMC OCONUS (Japan) commands by making it possible to safely move operational forces for home station training and deployments. The average vehicles are increasingly unreliable and are costly to maintain and negatively impact mission capability.
Funds in the amount of $0.136M will be used for the procurement of mission critical passenger vehicles (pickup trucks, vans, etc.) that is essential to the continuity of operating and maintaining 35K acres of Townsend Bombing Range (TBR) to accommodate air-to-ground delivery of precision guided munitions (PGM).
Funding increased from FY19 to FY20 by $0.768M to replace over-aged buses capable of transporting 33-60 passengers used for the intra shuttle services required to support Marine Corps Bases in Okinawa as well as procure passenger vehicles (pickup trucks and vans capable of seating 7-8 passengers) for Townsend Bombing Range (TBR).
Commercial Cargo Vehicles - $10.074M: Funds will recapitalize a portfolio of non-tactical vehicles such as low speed electric vehicles, various types of trailers (specialty, lowbed & flatbed) and trucks (fuel, stake-bed, nurse unit, semi-tractor, sewer maintenance & pickup). Recapitalization of over-aged vehicles provide safer non-tactical cargo vehicle support for transportation of things (TOT) necessary to move operational forces for home station training and deployment movements and to support operations and maintenance of Marine Corps Installations. On/off-road vehicles being procured for California Bases must comply with California Air Resource Board (CARB) to reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the coming decade while improving air quality. Non-compliance results in fines of $10k per day, per vehicle.
Funds in the amount of $0.370M will be used to procure mission critical commercial cargo vehicles (tractor trucks, low-boy trailers, etc.) to operate and maintain 35K acres of Townsend Bombing Range (TBR) to accommodate air-to-ground delivery of precision guided munitions (PGM).
Increase of $0.149M from FY19 to FY20 is due to addition of Townsend Bombing Range requirements.
Emergency Response Vehicles - $4.109M: Funds will procure fire trucks (pumpers/aerial), rescue trucks, and ambulances for Marine Corps activities and commands. The funds will also procure brush trucks and water extenders to maintain ranges, training areas and facilities on Marine Corps Installations.
DPRI Guam - $1.711M: Funds will procure an aerial ladder truck for the Government of Japan funded J-008 Fire Station for future Marine Corps Base Guam. Funding will also be used to procure one type 6 brush truck for the P-715 training ranges for future MCBG.
Increase of $2.328M from FY19 to FY20 is in support of DPRI Guam and additional emergency response vehicle requirements.
Marine Security Guard (Vehicles) - $8.238M - Funds the procurement of commercial vehicles for the Marine Security Guard based on the requirements of the particular command and country embassies.
The increase of $1.804 from FY19 to FY20 is due to the activation of new MSG detachments that will require the purchase of new armored vehicles to support secure transportation of MSGs around their respective country as DoS does not permit the use of personal vehicles. The increases from FY19 to FY20 also takes into consideration an increase to the unit cost of vehicles which is due to a change in vendor.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Motor Transport Modifications funds numerous essential modifications, initiatives, and new vehicle procurements that are required to address operational priorities, engineering change proposals, safety concerns, support equipment inefficiencies, tool malfunctions, product quality deficiencies, and other issues that affect vehicle reliability, safety, availability, and readiness. A proactive and focused approach ensures proper vehicle sustainment and life-cycle management and allows USMC to develop and implement improvements, as needed, to respond to the evolving requirements of the Marine Corps and sustain the fleet.
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) - The MTVR is the Marine Corps' medium ground lift capability supporting all elements of the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF). With its 70% off-road mission profile and the addition of a highly survivable armor package, the MTVR is heavily used in contingency operations as well as missions supporting humanitarian operations. It has a payload of 7.1 tons off-road and 15 tons on-road, a high-performance suspension, traction control, central tire inflation system, and automatic transmission, to transport personnel, ammunition, bulk cargo, and/or bulk fuel and water in a variety of environments. The MTVR family of vehicles includes a cargo variant (both standard and extended wheel base configurations), a dump truck, a wrecker, a tractor and a High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS) Rocket Resupply System Vehicle. This program funds numerous product improvements to the MTVR via engineering change proposals (ECPs), resulting from post-production requirements in Force Protection, Communications, on-board Situational Awareness, and improved fuel efficiency required across the Range of Military Operations, as well as addressing product quality deficiencies and other issues that impact vehicle safety, reliability, availability and readiness. The requirements capability change to improve Fuel Efficiency for the MTVR is part of the program's initiatives to lower fuel consumption and extend the vehicle's cruising range, while lowering operating costs over the life of the MTVR.
Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) Family of Vehicles (FoV): Provides Warfighters multi-mission platforms capable of mitigating Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs), underbody mines, and small arms fire threats. Multiple MRAP vehicle Categories (CATs) have been procured, fielded, and are now being sustained, such as the MRAP-All Terrain Vehicle (M-ATV), with combat operations (OPS) in rural, mountainous, and urban terrain. Category I - Urban combat operations, ambulance. Category II - Multi-mission ops-convoy lead, troop transport, ambulance, utility vehicle. Category III - Mine/IED clearance ops, explosive ordnance disposal. Funding includes required Government Furnished Equipment (GFE)/subsystems and ECP/Capability Insertion in response to an UUNS and Warfighter safety and survivability requirements.
P-19 Replacement (P-19R): Vehicles are replacing the obsolete A/S32P-19A Crash Fire Rescue fleet in support of expeditionary airfield operations and the supporting establishment. The vehicle is outfitted with advanced fire suppression equipment. It provides rescue and aircraft fire fighting capabilities to permanent and expeditionary airfields throughout the Marine Corps. The P-19R may also be employed to fight structural fires in support of base camps and as firefighting support to other elements of the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF), such as ammunition supply points, Petroleum, Oil, and Lubricant (POL) distribution points, or hazardous material storage facilities.
Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) Modification: The LVSR is the Marine Air-Ground Task Force Heavy Lift Capability system. The LVSR is built on the Oshkosh TAC-4 fully independent suspension, allowing it to traverse a variety of challenging terrain while carrying a payload of up to 22.5 tons. The LVSR accomplishes a variety of tactical logistics missions using armored and unarmored cargo tractor and recovery variants. Funding provides for modifications required for the LVSR fleet of vehicles, such as updated brackets and cables for warfighter systems such as legacy Blue Force Tracker upgraded to Joint Battle Command Platform and CREW Vehicle Receiver Jammer upgraded to CREW Vehicle Receiver Jammer V2. These modifications also include critical safety upgrades, which include the brake corrosion modification, which prevents brake failure due to submersion in water during fording, boat and bridge operations, and improved blast seats that reduce occupant injury during IED strikes. Finally, modifications include life cycle issues such as cab reconditioning, parts obsolescence and life cycle cost reductions.
Motor Transport Modification (MTM) - Light Tactical Family of Vehicles (FoV) - Modification program funds numerous essential modifications, initiatives, and new vehicle procurements that are required to address operational priorities, engineering change proposals, safety concerns, support equipment inefficiencies, tool malfunctions, product quality deficiencies, and other issues that affect vehicle reliability, availability and readiness. A proactive and focused approach ensures proper sustainment and life-cycle management of the light tactical vehicle fleet and allows the program office to develop and implement improvements, as needed, to respond to the evolving requirements of the Marine Corps.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
Funding changes after FY 2018 reflect the inclusion of funding for Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) vehicles previously funded in BLI 6520 and the P-19R vehicles previously funded in BLI 5006. Funding for these programs were realigned to BLI 5050 beginning in FY19 to centralize modification funding for USMC tactical vehicles.
FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $23.372M
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) Modification: $7.477M; Integration of ECP Kits for installation on over 300 MTVRs. Funding supported the procurements of calibration technologies that were transitioned to the Marine Corps from the Office of Naval Research (ONR) Future Naval Capability initiative to improve the MTVR's fuel efficiency to begin installing on the MTVR armored fleet during FY19.
Motor Transport Modifications (MTM) $3.598M; Funding provided for the implementation of the fleet service life extension initiatives, vehicles, quality deficiency resolutions, safety initiatives, transparent armor re-lamination and environmental/state transportation mandated vehicle changes. Provided support for ECP integration to include addressing deficiencies of HMMWV vehicles due to up armoring and age degradation of the fleet, testing and fielding efforts for hosted systems i.e. C4I, weapons, and intel that use light tactical vehicles as their base transportation mode.
Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) Modification: $12.105M; $.192M Reserve. Funding provided for various modifications required for the LVSR fleet of vehicles, such as for the integration of brackets and cables for warfighter systems, and for critical safety upgrades, including the brake corrosion ECP and the armored door lock improvements. These upgrades addressed issues that affect user safety, life cycle issues, obsolescence, and ultimately, life cycle cost reductions.
FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $11.392M
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) Modification: $7.147M; In FY19, MTVR has a three-tier integration effort that spans across Marine Corps Expeditionary Forces (MEFs), Marine Augmentation Program-Kuwait (MAP-K) and the Marine Forces-Reserve (MFR), for procuring and installing several required Modifications. These modification upgrades improve the ability of the Marine to "shoot, move, and communicate" by prioritizing the installation of the C4I (command, control, communications, computers, and intelligence) systems, upgrading the weapons mount kit, as well as the front and rear cab axle mounts that are required due to the addition of heavy armor. Additionally, installation of the Turret Gunner Restraint System (TGRS) provides rollover protection for the Marine in the turret using a full-body, six-point harness.
Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) Modification: $3.080M; $.215M Reserve. Provides for modifications required for the LVSR fleet of vehicles, such as updated brackets and cables for warfighter systems such as legacy Blue Force Tracker upgraded to Joint Battle Command Platform and CREW Vehicle Receiver Jammer upgraded to CREW Vehicle Receiver Jammer V2. These modifications also include critical safety upgrades which include the brake corrosion modification which prevents brake failure due to submersion in water during fording, boat and bridge operations, and improved blast seats that reduce occupant injury during IED strikes. Finally, modifications include life cycle issues such as cab reconditioning, parts obsolescence and life cycle cost reductions.
P-19 Replacement: $.218M.022M Reserves. Funding will provide initial support, training, Spares and FSRs for Reserves' vehicles. Funding in FY19 and out reflects P-19R vehicles previously in BLI 5006.
Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) Family of vehicles (FoV): $0.710M Funds ECP upgrades/modifications for the enduring MRAP vehicle requirement. Continues ECP Upgrades and Modifications to maintain vehicle relevancy in meeting force protection threats, such as blast, rollover or water submersion events, and responding to operational needs. Funding in FY19 and out reflects MRAP previously in BLI 6520.
FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $19.234M
Motor Transport Modifications (MTM) $.542M; Funding will provide for limited quality deficiency resolutions and safety initiatives. Provides the USMC portion of an engineering change proposal and associated technical manual updates that addresseperformance and safety deficiencies from the HMMWV family of vehicles operating in excess of the gross vehicle weight rating. The increase of $.542M from FY19 to FY20 restores funding in FY20 to support vehicle safety and reliability modifications/ECPs.
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) Modification: $14.501M; In FY20, MTVR's will continue to have a three-tier integration effort to meet approved operational requirements that span across Marine Corps Expeditionary Forces (MEFs), Marine Augmentation Program-Kuwait (MAP-K) and the Marine Forces-Reserve (MFR), for procuring and installing several types of modification kits. These modification upgrades improve the ability of the crew to "shoot, move, and communicate" by prioritizing the installation of the C4I (command, control, communications, computers, and intelligence) systems, upgrading the weapons mount kit to enable the employment of heavy machine guns, as well as the front and rear cab axle mounts that are required due to the addition of heavy armor. C4I kits enable the platform to accept Radios, Intercoms, Jammers and Blue Force Situational Awareness capabilities. Additionally, installation of the Turret Gunner Restraint System (TGRS) provides rollover protection for the Marine in the turret using a full-body, six-point harness. The increase of $7.354M between FY19 and FY20 is due to the cost of vehicle and ECP modification upgrades that are planned for procurement and installation in FY20; installation costs account for over half the total cost of each ECP.
Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) $.742M. Will procure ECP upgrades/modifications for the enduring MRAP vehicle requirement. Continues ECP upgrades and Modifications to maintain relevancy in meeting force protection threats, such as blast, rollover or water submersion events, and responding to operational needs. The increase of $.032M from FY19 to FY20 is the result of support of ECP upgrades.
P-19 Replacement (P-19R) $.179M; $.183M Reserve. Will procure engineering change proposals (ECPs), such as lightening arrestors. The increase of $.122M from FY19 to FY20 is the result of such ECPs to the new vehicle.
Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) $2.855M; $.232M Reserve. Will procure modified cabs which prevents deadlining the vehicle due to corrosion and modified seats to sustain the current level of performance of LVSR during IED strikes. The decrease of $.208M from FY19 to FY20 is the result of completion of LVSR door lock ECP.
OCO: FY 2019 OCO Appropriation Request: $44.440M
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) Modification: $18.001M; OCO funded procurement and installation of various ECP kits required for the MTVRs located in the Marine Expeditionary Unit (MEU) Augmentation Program-Kuwait (MAP-K), and other Marine units. The ECP Kits included the C4ISR kits which provide cabling and bracketry for the Joint Battle Command Platform (JBC-P) and Counter IED Systems (CVRJ); Rear Cab Mounts, Front Cab Mounts, the Automatic Fire Extinguishing System (AFES) and the Emergency Egress Window (EEW). These kits increase the overall survivability, safety and the Command, Control, Communication, Computers, Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) capabilities of the MTVR Armored Family of Vehicles.
Logistics Vehicle System Replacement: (LVSR): $.519M OCO. Will fund procurement and installation of Engineering Change Proposals (ECP), such as brake safety, JBC-P and counter IED Systems, CVRJs needed for the LVSRs located in the MAP-K. These kits increase force protection of all LVSR variants by ensuring the vehicles have updated ECPs to increase braking capability, navigation and counter IED threats.
Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) Family of Vehicles (FoV): $25.920M OCO. Funds the installation of Egress kits procured in response to UUNS 08275UC and 10215UC; MARCENT Enduring requirements. The Egress kit increases force protection on all Cougar CAT I and CAT II variants by ensuring that vehicle occupants can safely exit the vehicle after blast, rollover or water submersion events. FY18 - FY19 OCO overall increase of $21.920M (BLI 6520 FY18 $4.000M realigned to BLI 5050 FY19 $25.920M) for Cougar Egress Installation.

proc:Name.footnote: FY19 to FY20 difference of $6.914M is due to the FY19 OCO funding added in FY19 to satisfy the increasingly urgent need to provide Safety ECP's for MTVR's in theater.
The FY19 to FY20 difference of $4.056M is due to the OCO funding added in FY19 to satisfy the increasingly urgent need to provide Safety ECP's for MTVR's in theater.

Increase from FY19 to FY20 of $0.053M is for additional scheduled installations of the FE software kits on various tactical vehicles in the fleet during FY20; initial technical support for those SW kits included in cost.
FY19 to FY20 increase of $.270M is due to adjusted cost estimate to include additional support to process/analyze data as upgrades to fleet are completed.

FY19 to FY20 increase of $.507M restores funding to support safety and reliability modifications/ECPs such as body mounts for the HMMWV.
