proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Family of Internally Transportable Vehicles (FITV) are light weight and internally transportable in the V-22, CH-53D & CH53E tilt and rotary wing aircraft consisting of the Utility Task Vehicle (UTV), the future Ultra-Light Tactical Vehicle (ULTV), and the obsolete Internally Transportable Vehicle (ITV). The FITV provides deployed Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) and Marine Expeditionary Unit (Special Operations Capable) (MEU SOC) with vehicles, which are internally transportable in selected rotary and fixed wing aircraft. The FITV expeditionary vehicles support over-the-horizon amphibious operations, irregular warfare and enhanced company operations. The vehicles are fielded to infantry and reconnaissance communities. Speed, maneuverability, and the use of cover and concealment are the crew's primary means of survival.
The UTV is a part of the family of vehicles that supports the Marine Corps Operating Concept (MOC) by providing infantry and reconnaissance battalions with a reliable, easily maintained, inexpensive vehicle to support dispersed and disaggregated logistics operations while increasing unit mobility. The UTV fills a capability gap in motorized logistics sustainment, including casualty evacuation (CASEVAC) and Javelin/ammo transport for Marine Corps infantry units. UTV's are employed by the helo companies of the MEUs and Special Purpose (SP) MAGTFs as they execute heliborne and tiltrotor operations. This commercial off the shelf (COTS) solution mitigates the infantry battalion support gap, with the ability to operate in remote, rural regions where currently fielded ground mobility platforms are unsuitable due to size, weight, and safety concerns.
Based on USMC Expeditionary Fire Support System (EFSS) divestiture, the Marine Corps will divest of ITV prime mover and light strike variants and move toward modernization as Internally Transportable Vehicle (ITV) replacement alternatives are explored.
Efforts will begin to replace the Utility Task Vehicles (UTV) with the Ultra-Light Tactical Vehicle (ULTV). The replacement vehicle will be multirole, supporting Reconnaissance and Infantry communities by providing a deployed SP MAGTF and Marine Expeditionary Unit (Special Operations Capable) (MEU (SOC)) with an internally transportable vehicle to support over-the-horizon amphibious operations, irregular warfare and enhanced company operations as they execute heliborne and tiltrotor operations. The ULTV will replace the UTV fleet of vehicles with greater capability and will absorb and increase its mission. Increased capabilities planned include integration of communications and GPS equipment and serve as a crew-served weapons carrier.
The FITV line item will provide for the implementation of engineering change proposals, safety initiatives, and quality design resolutions to fielded UTVs. This hands-on method ensures proper in-service management and vehicle sustainment while allowing the program office to develop and implement improvements as needed to respond to evolving requirements of the Marine Corps that affect vehicle reliability, safety, availability and readiness. The last UTVs have a planned item exit date of 2022. Safety and reliability modifications are planned throughout its life to ensure maximum readiness as vehicles age.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY18 Base Appropriation Request: $1.266M
Funding provided product improvements to the existing UTV Fleet to address safety and reliability issues, engineering change proposals, as required, based upon feedback from the users of this COTS item in the operational environment.
FY19 Base Appropriation Request: $0.606M
Funding provides product improvement to the centrally managed UTV fleet for safety and reliability issues and engineering change proposals. The funds will also support the associated update of the technical documentation upon modification of the vehicles.
FY20 Base Appropriation Request: $0.648M
Funding provides for reliability engineering in support of product improvement to the UTV Fleet to address emergent fact of life reliability issues based on feedback from the operational users, such as the previously executed wheel well protection analysis and engineering change proposal that resulted in increased vehicle safety, reliability, and enhanced performance.
The increase of $0.042M is due to additional engineering change proposals required to ensure vehicle safety, reliability and enhanced performance associated with the aging UTV fleet.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: Family of Internally Trans Veh (ITV)
proc:P5Item.proc:Remarks: [Support Cost] Funding is provided for reliability engineering in support of product improvement to the UTV Fleet to address emergent fact of life reliability issues based on feedback from the operational users, including efforts similar to previously executed road march kits, all-terrain tires and floorboard reinforcement engineering change proposals that resulted in increased vehicle safety and reliability.

proc:Name.footnote: Prior year includes the procurement of 195 ITV Modification kits at a unit cost of $26,210.26 each, initial Contractor Logistics Support (CLS); 248 Utility Task Vehicles (UTVs) at a unit cost of $50,512.10 each and miscellaneous cost associated with the execution of the program requirements.
UTV's are deployed to the infantry battalions and the Reconnaissance units. Continuous feedback provided on these vehicles results in necessary safety modifications
FY19 will support the update of technical documentation associated with UTV vehicle improvements based on the modifications and engineering change proposals.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
This budget line item includes various procurements such as engineering efforts, engineering change proposals, modifications, and other related items less than $5 million each.
Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) Program provides a comprehensive approach to extend the useful life on Marine Corps tactical ground and ground support equipment. The CPAC Program Office is responsible for the governance, oversight and management of both preventive and corrective corrosion control encompassing Acquisition Engineering, Material Development, Corrosion Service Teams, and Corrosion Repair Facility activities. The Consolidated CPAC Program provides a total lifecycle solution focused on Total Ownership Cost reduction and improved readiness.
Engineer Mods and Tool Kits funds critical improvements to various pieces of equipment by enhancing their current capabilities and expanding protection from direct and indirect fire by providing specific tool kits, including the specific chest or case to store and transport the tools, to perform specific missions assigned to engineer units, such as carpentry, grubbing or clearing areas with pioneer type tools, destruction/demolition, masonry, electrical (base camp support), plumbing, etc. including (but not limited to) Construction Shopv Kit, Pioneer Platoon Kit, Pioneer Squad Kit, Carpenter Kit, Mason Kit, and tactical weld shop upgrades.
Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) provides Marine Corps Operating Forces with a fully intermodal transport capability emphasizing dimensional standardization and International Organization for Standardization compatibility. Containers such as Pallet (PALCONs), Quadruple (QUADCONs), Quadruple with Roll-up door (QUADCON RUD) and Joint Modular Intermodal Container (JMIC) are procured. Containers will replace locally assembled prefabricated wooden mount out boxes and flat box pallets. The containers will be used to support storage and movement of organizational property and consumable supplies; provide field, garrison and shipboard warehousing; and facilitate ship-to-shore movement. The Joint Modular Intermodal Container (JMIC) provides efficient, seamless, and visible movement of supplies and unit equipment throughout the transportation and distribution systems.
Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) is a family of systems line that contains purification, storage, distribution, hygiene, and test systems. This capability is necessary to provide safe and potable water to Marines in expeditionary environments. The family contains individual Table of Allowance Material Control Numbers which supports MAGTF operations by providing all aspects of land-based water support to include analysis, purification, reuse, storage, transfer and dispensing. The line contains items such as the Tactical Water Purification System (TWPS), Lightweight Water Purification System (LWPS), Expeditionary Water Distribution System (EWDS), Platoon Water Purification System (PWPS), Individual Water Purification System (IWPS), Forward Area Water Point Supply System, Pump Unit Set, Containerized Batch Laundry, Shower Systems, Gray Water Recycling, as well as all the various water supply support and analysis components and equipment including Six Container (SIXCON) Pump and Tank Modules, Nozzles, Interconnection Sets, Water Packaging Components, 3k/5k/25k Tanks, Hypocholorination Units, Water Quality Analysis Sets.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY2018 Base Appropriation Request: $8.477M (ACTIVE: $8.395M/RESERVE $0.082M)
Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) $0.867M: Funds the procurement of equipment protective covers designed to reduce and/or eliminate the negative effects of corrosion on USMC ground tactical and support equipment, and replacement of aging covers that have exceeded their expected life cycle to prevent failure in the field. The priority will be to provide equipment covers for equipment at II MEF, MARFORRES, and MARSOC for USMC equipment placed in an administrative staging program to mitigate the negative impacts of corrosion and decrease total ownership costs. Additionally, procurement funding will be used to replace antiquated blast and painting equipment at the Corrosion Repair Facilities (CRF's) located at I MEF, II MEF, and III MEF which are managed by the consolidated CPAC program monitoring the health on 92,758 tactical ground and support equipment assets.
Engineer Modification Kits (EMK) $4.086M: Continues to fund EMK for equipment armor installations, upgrades and safety concerns to prevent deterioration in Fleet readiness for Engineer Systems inventory consisting over 47,000 end items associated to 120 TAMCNs. Funds Assault Breacher Vehicle (ABV) IA support through Toughbook procurement and refresh, modifications and upgrades to fielded legacy as well as newly fielded systems and provides quick response capability for meeting Fleet Marine Force sustainment for safety engineering, readiness, Quality Deficiency Report analysis, and legacy system modifications.
Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) $1.298M: Procured Joint Modular Intermodal Containers. Funding required to meet the Approved Acquisition Objectives (AAO) outlined in the Total Force Structure Management System.
Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) $2.226M: ACTIVE: $2.144M/RESERVES $0.082M: Funds procure Platoon Water Purification System and supports the procurement of a critically needed ECPs for the M80 Water Heater.
FY2019 Base Appropriation Request: $11.608M (ACTIVE: $11.098M/RESERVE: $0.510M)
Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) $0.885M: The consolidated CPAC program currently monitors the corrosion condition of 112,672 tactical ground and support equipment assets. FY19 funding continues to procure equipment protective covers designed to reduce and/or eliminate the negative effects of corrosion on USMC ground tactical and support equipment and the replacement of aging covers that have exceeded their life expectancy. The priority will be to provide equipment covers throughout the Operating Forces for equipment placed in an administrative staging program to mitigate the negative impacts of corrosion and decrease total ownership costs. Procurement funding will also be used for the fielding and replacement of various equipment such as aging blast and painting equipment and hazardous and waste reduction equipment at the Corrosion Repair Facilities (CRFs) located at I MEF, II MEF and III MEF (Okinawa and Hawaii).
Engineer Modification Kits (EMK) $5.373M (ACTIVE: $5.194M/RESERVE: $0.179M): Additional funding provides upgrades to Modified-Full Width Mine Plows (M-FWMP), Deep Water Forging Kit (DWFK), FSR sustainment support and Tech Manual updates for the Assault Breacher Vehicle (ABV). Funds Improved Ribbon Bridge (IRB) Hinge modernization kit increasing the Reliability, Availability, and Maintainability (RAM) lowering future sustainment costs. Funds the Husky and Husky Mounted Detection System FSRs and the Instrument Set, Reconnaissance & Surveying Army system to maintain the Authority to Operate and keep pace with the Army system configuration. Continues to fund EMK for equipment armor installations, upgrades and safety concerns to prevent deterioration in Fleet readiness for Engineer Systems inventory consisting of over 47,000 end items associated to 120 TAMCNs. Supports modifications and upgrades to fielded legacy as well as newly fielded systems and provides quick response capability for meeting Fleet Marine Force sustainment for safety engineering, readiness, Quality Deficiency Report analysis, and legacy system modifications.
Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) $1.087M: Funds Joint Modular Intermodal Containers. The JMIC is a collapsible, durable, reusable, easy-to-handle, modular packaging container that can operate world-wide, carried by various modes of transportation, and is envisioned for future use as a compliment to Navy seabasing efforts for automatic loading, handling, and storage systems. The JMIC will enable Marines to fulfill their mission by giving the unit commander the flexibility to configure a mobile/deployable container as necessary to meet the specific mission of the unit. It provides the operating forces with a fully intermodal transport capability which lays flat when not in use. The JMIC also provides a more effective use of storage areas in particularly limited storage facilities. Funding is required to meet the Approved Acquisition Objective outlined in the Total Force Structure Management System.
Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) $4.263M (ACTIVE: $3.932M/RESERVES $0.331M): Funds procure PWPS and supports the procurement of a critically needed ECP for the M80 Water Heater. The increase in funding from FY18 to FY19 $2.329M supports procurement of PWPS and a critically needed ECP for the M80 water Heater.
FY2020 Base Appropriation Request: $10.956M (ACTIVE: $10.585M/RESERVE: $0.371M)
Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) $0.895M: The consolidated CPAC program monitors the corrosion condition of 112,672 tactical ground and support equipment assets. FY20 funding will continue to procure equipment protective covers designed to reduce and/or eliminate the negative effects of corrosion on USMC ground tactical and support equipment and the replacement of aging covers that have exceeded their life expectancy. The priority will be to provide equipment covers throughout the Operating Forces for equipment placed in an administrative staging program to mitigate the negative impacts of corrosion and decrease total ownership costs. Procurement funding will also be used for the fielding and replacement of various equipment such as aging blast and painting equipment and hazardous waste reduction equipment at the Corrosion Repair Facilities (CRFs) located at I MEF, II MEF and III MEF (Okinawa and Hawaii).
Engineer Modification Kits (EMK) $3.777M: Continues to fund EMK for equipment armor installations, upgrades and safety concerns to prevent deterioration in Fleet readiness for Engineer Systems inventory consisting of over 47,000 end items associated to 120 TAMCNs. Funding provides upgrades to mine plows; FSR sustainment support and TM updates for the Assault Breacher Vehicles (ABV); and IA support through Toughbook procurement and refresh. Supports modifications and upgrades to fielded legacy as well as newly fielded systems and provides quick response capability for meeting Fleet Marine Force sustainment for safety engineering, readiness, Quality Deficiency Report analysis, and legacy system modifications. Decrease of $1.417M from FY19 to FY20 reflects realignment ($1.350M) from EMK to Assault Breacher Vehicle (ABV) BLI 6520 to improve accountability ($0.067M) and reflects completion of modifications and upgrades to fielded systems.
Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) $1.213M: Funds equipment such as Joint Modular Intermodal Containers. The JMIC is a collapsible, durable, reusable, easy-to-handle, modular packaging container that can operate world-wide, carried by various modes of transportation, and is envisioned for future use as a compliment to Navy seabasing efforts for automatic loading, handling, and storage systems. The JMIC will enable Marines to fulfill their mission by giving the unit commander the flexibility to configure a mobile/deployable container as necessary to meet the specific mission of the unit. It provides the operating forces with a fully intermodal transport capability which lays flat when not in use. The JMIC also provides a more effective use of storage areas in particularly limited storage facilities. Funding is required to meet the Approved Acquisition Objective outlined in the Total Force Structure Management System. The increase in funding of $0.126M from FY19 to FY20 supports the plan to procure increased quantity of JMICs to meet AAO.
Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) $5.071M (ACTIVE: $4.700M/RESERVES $0.371M): Funds will procure Platoon Water Purification System (PWPS). The increase in funding from FY19 to FY20 $0.808M supports procurement Platoon Water Purification System (PWPS) program of record.

proc:Name.footnote: -FY18 PMC Active JMIC Quantity decreased by 163 due to step ladder pricing and cost difference associated with it as a result of being incrementally funded. Another cost element added to reflect pricing for quantities less than 300 each. -FY17 PMC Active JMIC Quantity increased by 3 each (Increase from 37 to 40) due to funding movement from Reserves 0502514M) to active (0206315M) and funding not required for Integrated Logistics Support. FY18 PMC slight pricing change due to quantity greater than 300 each (Contract Tier Pricing). -FY17 PMC Active JMIC Quantity increased by 6 each(Increase from 31 to 37) due to available funding not required for Integrated Logistics Support. -FY17 PMC Active supported remaining QuadCon RUD procurement. JMIC Active quantity decreased from 79 to 31; JMIC Procurement quantity increases with FY17 Reserves. Reference JMIC-Reserves Cost Element for FY17. -JMIC Contract Modification resulted in slight pricing change in FY17 and FY18. -FY18 through FY22; funds moved from Reserves (0502514M) to Active (0206315M). -FY16 and prior year funds reside in BLI 6543.
-FY18 Funding: Due to step ladder pricing; prices increase for quantities less than 300 each. Receipt of incremental funding resulted in quantities less than 300.

FY18 funds were delayed for PWPS due to a 6+ month slip in the Request For Proposal Release which reduced planned production quantities to Product Verification Test quantities. Full Rate Production starts FY19. The RFP was released and PWPS is currently in Source Selection Testing with a contract award scheduled for 3QFY19. FY19 funding is for (14) Limited Production quantities to use for Product Verification Testing. FY20 funding is for (166) Production quantities.
FY19 funds will be used to refurbish PWPS Product Verification Test equipment for fielding as well as Product Verification Testing costs at numerous DoD test facilities.

proc:Item.proc:Name: 4.3) Platoon Water Purification System Product Verification Testing

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Spares - Funds are required to reimburse the Navy Working Capital Fund for both repairable and consumable components at the time the initial spare parts package is released with the principal end item (PEI) to the Fleet Marine Force. This concept complies with the Navy Working Capital Fund funding of Initial Spares with reimbursement from the Procurement Account. Funds also provide for direct vendor support of the PEI delivery to the Fleet Marine Force.
This account has funding for the following programs: Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T), Tactical Remote Sensor System (TRSS), Intelligence Analysis System (IAS), Terrestrial Collection, LAV-Anti Tank System Program, LAV Reset Program, M1A1 Modification, Family of Material Handling Equipment (FMHE), Ground/Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR AN/TPS-80), RQ-21A Small Tactical UAS, General Purpose Tool and Test Systems (GPTTS), Amphibious Combat Vehicle Increment 1.1 (ACV 1.1), and Training Simulation Support (TSS)/Training Devices.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $29.109M ($28.747M Active; $0.362M Reserve)
ACV 1.1 BLI 2025: $5.569M procured initial spares for communication suites, Driver's Vision Enhancer, Exportable Power, Joint Battle Command-Platform (JBC-P), and Amphibious Remote Weapon Stations (ARWS).
M1A1 Modification Kits BLI 2061: Reserve $0.362M procured the remaining reserve spares for the Abrams Integrated Display and Targeting System (AIDATS).
General Purpose Tool and Test Equipment BLI 4181: $0.173M supported reimbursement to the working capital funds for spares acquired and needed during test support.
SMART-T BLI 4633: $0.205M provided direct vendor support of the principal end item (PEI) components that reduced repair time and equipment downtime.
AN/TPS-80 Ground Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR) BLI 4655: $11.417M procured spares for the Gallium Nitride (GaN) LRIP systems.
RQ-21 UAS BLI 4737: $11.027M procured initial spares for 4 RQ-21A systems as well as support sparing for deployments in that year.
TRSS BLI 4747: $0.356M purchased equipment spares in the TRSS System of Systems (SoS) that minimized repair time and equipment unavailability.
FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $24.397M
ACV 1.1 BLI 2025: $6.145M provides for initial spares for communication suites, Driver's Vision Enhancer, Exportable Power, Joint Battle Command-Platform (JBC-P), and Amphibious Remote Weapon Stations (ARWS). Initial spares for ACV 1.1 are procured commensurate with the end items they support based on lead time for procurement.
LAV Reset BLI 2038: $5.735M procures spares for direct vendor support required for the fielding of the Reset kits on the Light Armored Vehicle.
General Purpose Tool and Test Equipment BLI 4181: $0.174M funding supports reimbursement to the working capital funds for spares acquired and needed during test support.
SMART-T BLI 4633: $0.207M provides funds for the direct vendor support of the principal end item (PEI) components to reduce repair time and equipment downtime for the Warfighter.
AN/TPS-80 Ground Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR) BLI 4655: $11.611M provides spares funding to support Gallium Nitride (GaN) LRIP systems procured in FY18. FY19 Spares funding is required to procure the initial provisioning package to primarily support those GaN LRIP systems being procured in FY18 and fielded in FY20, as over 90 percent of the G/ATOR spares have a lead time exceeding 12 months. The spares funding increases ($0.194M) from FY18 to FY19 supporting the fielding of four (4) new systems in FY20 for a total of thirteen (13) G/ATOR systems fielded through FY20. Adequate sparing is necessary so Marine Operational Forces will have the necessary repair parts to operate and maintain newly fielded G/ATOR Radar Systems and to avoid a significant risk of not meeting the program's important Key Performance Parameter (KPP) 8; Sustainment.
IAS BLI 4747: $0.160M of spares funding provides for direct vendor support of the principal end item (PEI) components delivery to the Fleet Marine Force.
Terrestrial Collection BLI 4747: $0.261M provides for purchase of equipment spares necessary to keep ground-based imagery collection and dissemination assets and sensor systems in operation, ensuring spares are available to the warfighter when breakage occurs to minimize equipment down-time.
Training Simulation Support (TSS)/Training Devices BLI 6532: $0.051M funds procurement of low density, minor (low cost) MAGTF ground training equipment, simulators and simulations to include devices such as medical training kits, climbing walls, weapons models and mockups that enhance basic occupational and combat skills across the wide spectrum of tactics, techniques, procedures and proficiency.
Family of Material Handling Equipment (FMHE) BLI 6544: $0.053M provides for the replacement and Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) of Marine Corps MHE such as forklifts, cranes, and container handlers. This budget line item also includes funding for equipment such as the Light Capability Rough Terrain Forklift (LCRTF), Hydraulic Excavator (HYEX), Extendable Boom Forklift Modernization (EBFL-M), Rough Terrain Container Handler (RTCH) SLEP and the Tractor, Rubber Tires, and Articulated Steering, Multiple Purpose (TRAM) SLEP.
FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $33.470M
The funding increase of $9.073M from FY19 to FY20 is primarily due to the ACV 1.1 Spares increase of $7.809M, which is a direct result of the increase in ACV vehicles and GFE being procured in BLI 2025 in FY20.
ACV 1.1 BLI 2025: $13.954M will provide for initial spares for communication suites, Driver's Vision Enhancer, Exportable Power, Joint Battle Command-Platform (JBC-P), and Amphibious Remote Weapon Stations (ARWS). Initial spares for ACV 1.1 are procured commensurate with the end items they support based on lead time for procurement. The increase of $7.809M between FY 2019 and FY 2020 is attributed to increased quantity of ACV vehicles in FY 2020 and government furnished equipment (GFE) in support of Full Rate Production.
LAV Reset Program BLI 2038: $5.883M funding will provide spares for direct vendor support required for the fielding of the Reset kits on the Light Armored Vehicle.
General Purpose Tool and Test Equipment BLI 4181: $0.178M funding will procure equipment spares for newly fielded mechanical test equipment, electrical test equipment, and tool sets and kits. Funding ensures critical spares are available to the warfighter when breakage occurs to minimize equipment down time.
AN/TPS-80 Ground Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR) BLI 4655: $13.235M provides spares funding to support the Lot One Full Rate Production (FRP) systems procured in FY19. FY20 spares funding is required to procure the initial provisioning package (IPP) which consists of over one hundred assemblies/parts with over 60 critical items to include Five-Axis Motor Controllers and Dual Leaf Assemblies. Funding will primarily support the Lot One FRP systems being procured in FY19 and fielded in FY21, as over 90 percent of the G/ATOR spares have a lead time exceeding 12 months. Thus, the FY20 spares funding will obligate in FY20 and begin to deliver Spares in FY21 to align with end item systems deliveries. The spares funding increase ($1.624M) from FY19 to FY20 supports the fielding of six (6) new systems beginning in FY21 for a total of nineteen (19) G/ATOR systems fielded through CY21. The funding in FY20 is also required for the decentralized distribution of initial spares from LOGCOM to the Repair Inventory Points at each Marine Expeditionary Force, as required. Adequate sparing is necessary so Marine Operational Forces will have the necessary repair parts to operate and maintain newly fielded G/ATOR Radar Systems and to avoid placing the program at significant risk of not meeting its important Key Performance Parameter (KPP) 8 of Sustainment.
Intelligence Analysis System (IAS) BLI 4767: $0.166M of spares funding will provide for direct vendor support of the principal end item (PEI) components delivery to the Fleet Marine Force.
Family of Material Handling Equipment (FMHE) BLI 6544: $0.054M provides for the replacement and Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) of Marine Corps MHE such as forklifts, cranes, and container handlers. This budget line item also includes funding for equipment such as the Light Capability Rough Terrain Forklift (LCRTF), Hydraulic Excavator (HYEX), Extendable Boom Forklift Modernization (EBFL-M), Rough Terrain Container Handler (RTCH) SLEP and the Tractor, Rubber Tires, and Articulated Steering, Multiple Purpose (TRAM) SLEP.
